reviewText:
Recommended with some reservations.....

“It’s as if Limbo and Bioshock Infinite had a baby while watching Pan’s Labyrinth”
VENTUREBEAT

No, just no. It's as if Echochrome II & Rain dry humped to an episode of Sesame Street. The game from a conceptual point of view has so much in it's favour - noir setting, the shadow based puzzles, a storyline & characters which have potential to be interesting.

In my eyes however the noir setting and general atmosphere is flat and lifeless given the themes and what they had to work with. The shadow based puzzles are simplistic and clumsy in the majority of cases favouring artsy fartsy stylings over the kind of truly satisfying, mind bending puzzles you'd get from say Echochrome/shift, Portal or Swapper. The storyline almost offers redemption with gray areas being left for the player to fill in the gaps based on scraps of information gained from collectibles, info within the lighthouse and the game ending.

That said, this is a positive review. I played to completion & enjoyed it - the metascores are correct, it's a 6/10 game which had huge potential but falls short in so many areas and relies heavily on styling.

reviewText:
Recommended with some reservations.....

“It’s as if Limbo and Bioshock Infinite had a baby while watching Pan’s Labyrinth”
VENTUREBEAT

No, just no. It's as if Echochrome II & Rain dry humped to an episode of Sesame Street. The game from a conceptual point of view has so much in it's favour - noir setting, the shadow based puzzles, a storyline & characters which have potential to be interesting.

In my eyes however the noir setting and general atmosphere is flat and lifeless given the themes and what they had to work with. The shadow based puzzles are simplistic and clumsy in the majority of cases favouring artsy fartsy stylings over the kind of truly satisfying, mind bending puzzles you'd get from say Echochrome/shift, Portal or Swapper. The storyline almost offers redemption with gray areas being left for the player to fill in the gaps based on scraps of information gained from collectibles, info within the lighthouse and the game ending.

That said, this is a positive review. I played to completion & enjoyed it - the metascores are correct, it's a 6/10 game which had huge potential but falls short in so many areas and relies heavily on styling.

reviewText:
Contrast is a good game. Nothing more, nothing less just good. It's a complete game, but it also feel like its EXACTLY wanted the devepoer wanted to accomplish. While platforming is the main gameplay component, and its ok, its the story that is the real focus and that focus is easily highlighted by the biggest suprise, game length. I would have easily guessed there would be 8-10 hours of gameplay as most platformers fall in that range, but searching every corner, taking my time, reading all the notes, etc my total time is right at 4 hours. Could it have easily been 10hrs, yes. Did i want to spendmore time in this world with these charcters, definantly. I have never measured a game by its length(wink!) and neither should anyone. Its gameplay, story, mechanics, world, music and charcters that you want to find yourself lost and for Contrast i was glad no one found me.

Positives
Twilight Zonish story
Really good voice work
Beutiful art, noire world
Good platforming
Easy game, short
Easy to get all achievments
Cool easter eggs

Negatives

Short-would like to have spent more time in the world with these charcters
sound- Other than main menu soundtrack there is very little to no music. Also, during some sequences in shadow no sound?
Platforming is basic. Does not take adavantage of the charcter who is an acrobat

reviewText:
Short Version:
---------------------
+ Nice visuals
+ Nice music
+ Unique game mechanics
+ Interresting puzzles
+ good story (not great, but ok)

- Short playtime
- Can get a bit frustrating if you have to try some things over and over again

[ Hint for german people: ~ Voice acting is english, subs are german ]

Recommended? Yes, but only if you can get it in a deal

Long Version:
-------------------
This games is something different... It's some kind of a puzzle game with a good story, nice visuals and great music. Didi wants to get her father back to her family and you have to help her. To do so, you have to fix some things and open the way where didi is not able to get through. The interresting thing here are the game mechanics. You have to move objects in front of lights sources to change the shadows on the walls. Then you can step into the walls so that you can move along these shadows. You have to take objects with you when you are a shadow on the wall, to bring them to the place where you need them. And so on. Thats quite unique and a pretty nice idea. It is really fun, to figure out which step you need to do next, to solve all these puzzles. BUT: I finished this game in about 3 hours with almost all the collectable items (I missed 2 Items somewhere) This is a bit short in my opinion and this is the reason why I would recommend, to buy this game if you can get it in a deal and not for the full price. So if you can get it for cheap and you wanna try something different and you like to solve puzzles then buy this game ;)

reviewText:
Contrast is a strange beast. It's a platform-based puzzle game set in a surrealist, steampunk, early 20th century paris-like city. The player controls Dawn, the imaginary friend of the main character Didi, who has the titular power of being able to switch back and forth from the physical world to the shadow world. The player uses this ability to solve the many puzzles that are conviently wrapped around the story line. I don't want to delve too deep into the lore of this story, since most of its value comes from its twists (which is bad enough that I'm addressing), but it is something to witness. I wish that the game explored certain aspects that I felt needed developing, and the ending was a bit lackluster.

I have two main quips about this game. The first is its glitches. Sometimes when doing certain puzzles in the shadow world, the game will inexplicably pop you back into the physical world. Puzzles like these just require trial and error, but in a game where the main goal is to challenge the player's smarts and not their patience, it has no place. The second quip I have is the length of the game. It only took me three and a half hours to finish this game, and I usually consider myself as someone who plays through games very slowly. Since I actually got this game as a gift from a very generous friend (thanks BOT Mathew :3), I'm not that mad about it. However, if you plan on buying this game, ONLY GET IT ON SALE. It is definetely not worth a full $15. Other than that, I love this game. The controls are great, the visuals are engaging, and the collectibles give an excuse to marvel at such a beautifull world.

TL; DR: A very pretty game with an interesting story and even more interesting puzzles, yet can get a little buggy at times and is too much for its price considering its length. A must get game while its on sale. Can be considered one of those art" games.

Overall Score: 6.5-7"

reviewText:
For the full price - forget about it. When there is a  big sale   on, something around 75% off - still think twice. The The whole game is a series of disappointinng shortfalls. Here's my story explaning why:

I noticed Contrast over a year ago and the concept of the game, coupled with what I saw on the trailers and in the screenshots, had me really wanting this game. The price though was a bit steep, so I only got it on sale recently. And I'm mighty glad I waited. Without further ado, here's what's wrong with the game.

First of all, the story feels like scribbled down on a knee five minutes before the writers had a deadline to submit it. Nothing to keep the player interested, just a generic tale of a child and her parents don't quite form a perfect family. The characters, save the protagonist, are shallow, one-dimensional and there's little reason for anyone to form any sort of emotional bond with them. The only chance of livening up the plot  when the player discovers collectibles pertaining to Dawn and Vincenzo in the last act  is merely reduced to finding some collectibles and one scene just before the credits.

Secondly, the gameplay is, to put it bluntly, rubbish. Platformers in the 90's offered better game mechanics. The fantasticly promising concept of manipulating lights and shifting between shadows and the 'real' world is there just so you can jump on some platforms and move one or two boxes around. Nothing else. And one more thing here: the player character gains some skills for no apparent reason and then hardly ever uses them.

The controls are simple but even there you can find an issue, as the shifting mechanism often has a mind of its own and Dawn gets thrown off the platforms without the fault on the side of the player.

Graphics. To be fair, the game looks alright. Nothing remarkable though. The models are edgy, locations deserted for the most part (I'm talking here about items, not characters - the lack of the latter is just part of the game) but the overall feeling is positive. The atmosphere in the locations is nice, kind of gloomy and decadent at the same time.

On the other hand, the animations is where the game should deliver and fails completely. The protagonist is said to be an acrobat. Therefore, her moves should be fluent, graceful and light, which they only are when the character is walking slowly or standing still and I'm not convinced that this should be the case in an action game. The animations of Dawn interacting with objects or moving stuff, as well as thhe animations of all other characters feel terribly outdated.

Finally, the music, where the game promises much but delivers little. Despite what you might think having seen the trailers, there is in fact very litle music in the game. Soundtrack activates only when the player apporaches a certain location. Truth be told, the best piece of music was the one in the main menu. Character voicing is just wrong, its highlight being Dawn, who simply says nothing throughout the entire game.

Fortunately, Contrast is a very short game, in jusr 4 hours I manged to obtain a 100% playthrough. I say fortunately because I could not bear any more of the feeling that there's a game that could have been brilliant and turned out mediocre.
Pros:
Great noir setting
Fairly good graphics
Some nice music
Great protagonistCons:
Light/shadow manipulation reduced to one power
Uninteresting, unoriginal storyline
All other characters except the protagonist
Very short
Animations from 15 years ago
Gameplay from 20 years ago
Imprecise controls
Wasted potential everywhere
A final note: the ending hints, rather obviously, at a sequel. Unless the developers do some serious work to deliver a more complete experience with a story and gameplay to match its lovely graphics style its going to be, at least for me, a flop. So a word to the producers: Please, please do it right, because I so want the concept to be given the game it deserves.

Astonishingly beautiful.

The gameplay is unique. The art directions and music compositions are both fantastic and well used in the game.

reviewText:
This game is beautiful, just beautiful. The setting, the character design, the music, the atmosphere - all are spot-on.

It's more puzzles than platformers, and the puzzles have a habit of looking terribly difficult at first, but aren't too hard to figure out, and solving them made me feel all smart and smarmy :)

Platforming gameplay is easy to pick up on, controls are fine, it's good fun.

Only negative points are it's length (3.5 hours left me craving for more !) and (and this is a minor nitpick really) the fact that the black screen before cutscenes last just a little bit too long.

All in all, great experience, well worth the money, would absolutely buy again.

reviewText:
Intro:
Well I first noticed this game shortly after I started playing Bioshock Infinite. It cought my eye because of it's art style. After watching the trailers, I added this to my wishlist and purchased it during Winter Sale.

Well I'm not sure how to rate this game. It's really well done in the visual and aural departments. The atmosphere really transports that 20s France feeling. But there are some things to be improved.

Graphics:
Not much to rant about. Maybe that's because im easy to plese with graphics, as long as they just fit together. But there are some glitches, especially on movable objects (crates and balls). The puddles on the streets look more like ice than water. That's because there is no added effect if you walk through them.

Audio:
Also nothing to really complain. The music is well done and fits the scenery. I really like the track that runs during the menu screen. The voice acting is okay except for Didi. Her lines just sound strange" every now and then.

Controls:
My main complaint. It just feels like one of those early cheap 3D games. I often had problems judging how far I could jump. It just doesn't feel right. But I got used to it after a while.

Gameplay:
You spend a lot of time shifting into the shadows to acomplish your tasks. Sometimes the engine seems to have problems if the surface you are moving on is not even. If there is a corner
date: that's also a problem sometimes. But at least once the game forces you to go around a corner (which is evenly lit)
recommended:
so it cannot be intentional that the game throws you out of the shadow realm.

Sometimes there are new things to consider when solving puzzles. Unlike in many other games you are not shown that those concepts are there. Like shifting certain objects with you or moving objects using spotlights. I'm not really sure if this is a good thing or not. But I really liked finding those things out by myself. Maybe some optional hints would solve this "problem" for both sides.

Story:
To make it short: No epicness
hoursPlayed: no world rescue
voteText: no over the top characters
helpfulPercent: no "only he/she can do it". But nothing that special either... but as there hasn't been a story one could call "groundbreaking" or "has never been done before" in the recent past
votesHelpful:
I really like that simplicity.

Conclusion:
An artistically nice game with a few control hiccups that doesn't do handholding and is solvable without the use of walkthroughs or FAQs. Tells a down to earth fantasy story without uneccesary epicness. Buy it if you like artistically interesting games that don't neccessarily appeal to the masses.

EDIT:
What I really forgot:
It would've been nice if there was some more interaction with Didi. She often just stands there and does nothing. It only was about two times that she assisted you in one way or the other. For example: the screenshot where she lights the way with a lamp? Never happened."

reviewText:
Contrast is small, but it makes big in our hearts.

We take the roll of Dawn, a shadow presence only seen by a small girl named Didi. The youngster is curious about the world, and has a dream; bring her family together.
While we use the shadows to solve puzzles and protect Didi, we get ourselves wrapped in a plot to help Didi's family, or what's left of it. A father who is involved in shady mob-business, a mother who sings at a club, and a strange magician who is somehow related to Didi. A beautiful plot within an even gorgeous 1920's atmosphere, full of hopes and dreams disguised in the deadly shadows of the alleys.

Although the puzzles start on an easy way, it soon requires you do make use of your grey cells, and when you’re really enjoying, it ends...!
Collecting achievements is fun, and will maybe give you a reason to go back a second time.
Overall the game presents a nice experience, with a nice soundtrack that take you back several decades to an era of glamour.

I give it a 7/10. It's amazing, but short. Twice the length, and it would be a solid 9!

reviewText:
This is a game full of nice ideas and features a great little story delivered through clever platform and puzzle mechanics. Contrast also has a beautifully crafted film noir style 1920s world which is beyond beautiful and the soundtrack simply fits perfectly with the game and setting. The music captures 1920s cabart jazz and includes original tracks from Laura Ellis. Indeed checking out Cissie Redgwicks - Gimme That Swing (was used in the game trailer) is worth you time.

The story features a little girl called Didi and you play the role of her dimesion hopping imaginery friend called Dawn. However as Dawn you can only see the shadows and voices of the people Didi interacts with. But you will also see an adult world through the eyes of Didi as she tries to understand grown-up problems and tries desperately to get her parents back together. You will need to slip in and out of the shadows to complete objectives and you will often find the need to move light sources such as stage lamps or three-dimensional objects to cast the shadows, which Dawn can then navigate in 2D and progress with Didi. Controls are simple and intuitive and dying does not impose any penalties, (I played with 360 controller) experimentation is encouraged.

Definately worth the asking price. Now go buy it.

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10
Overview: 3D Platformer/Puzzle

The Good

+ Nice noir art style

+ Realistic lighting effects

+ The main gameplay mechanic allows you to transform into a shadow and platform on other shadows. By
manipulating real world objects you can create new shadows and reach new areas.

+ A good story that gets more detailed with each collectable you find

+ Easy achievements

+ Soundtrack

The Average:

The puzzles are a bit easy, I would have liked a bit more challenge given the cool gameplay
mechanic.


The Bad:

The game in incredibly short. I was able to complete the game in around 2 hours with very little effort.

Sometimes you will pop out of the shadows for no reason making platforming a frustrating experience.


Conclusion:

A fun if not short game. By the time the game starts finding its grove, its over

reviewText:
Nicely styled art direction, a solid core mechanic, and a well paced and well told narrative are what make video games unique and interesting and Contrast has these in spades. Beautifully designed, this is an excellent showcase of developer talent and I hope to see more from Compulsion Games.

Contrast follows Dawn, a mysterious woman with the ability to meld into shadows, as she accompanies Didi, a bright young girl who won't give up, on an adventure through the abstract and shadowy reflection of the 1920s. The game itself is short, I completed it in 5 hours but many of you might take less time. As with any game with a similar length, one can't talk about the plot without giving anything away and playing the game for any amount of time will plunge you straight in.

The main mechanic of this puzzle platformer is the ability to shift into two dimensions and move along the shadows as though they are solid objects. Perspective puzzles are a favorite of this game, as are weighing down switches with boxes. Admittedly the controls, while mostly solid, are sometimes fickle. One puzzle towards the end took me much longer than the others; not because it was hard to figure out but because it was difficult to wrestle the object into place. one aspect of the game I felt could be done better is the collection of Iluminaries, objects used to power the machines in the game. while there are a surplus of them in each level, the game has a nasty habit of locking doors behind you. So in theory, if you failed to collect enough of these things when you had the chance then progression becomes impossible; though this was not the case for me, be sure to follow your instincts and deal with the main objective last.

At the end of the day I think this game has a lot of ambition behind it and, despite a few hiccups here and there, was very tight and well designed. The game does feel a little bare bones but as with the hiccups I'm expecting that the next game by the Compulsion will solve these issues. I can definitely recommend this game and others from this up and coming developer.

reviewText: What a strange game this is. Is a bad game? No.  If you like light (no pun intended) puzzle games with an Ok narrative an good music and art direction you are going to enjoy this. Is short, the mechanics are pretty clear aside of one puzzle, with an easy solution if you just ignore what the game is teaching you up to that moment  (what is doing is introducing a new mechanic), but is nothing really horrible in the grand scheme of things, the collectibles are pretty easy to spot (some are tied to the story of the game wich is something that i really don´t like in games but in this case it kind of didn´t matter really much) and you are not gonna be heavily challenged by it.  If you are not in that side of the playing field,  this game is not for you\nOn the other hand, when i finished i couldn´t shake the feeling that this game somehow loses the opportunitty of being something really special, because it has a lot of potential, puzzles could be more interesting and the story coud have  packed a lot more punch in the emotional side.  I know that is a little unfair to punish a game for what it could have been an it isn´t, but some games show hints of what could have been an amazing experience and you can avoid that kind of sourness in your mouth,  but, like i said, if you like this kind of games and have little time in your hands to play or you want some palate cleanser between more intense experiences this is a game you should enjoy, i certainly did it, but damn, it could have been really good

reviewText:
A hidden gem. 8.5/10

You can tell a lot of love went into making this game. It's original, intelligent, about the right length (approx 5-6 hours), relaxing gaming fun with a very different game mechanic (once you get used to switching between 2D/3D), puzzles just about the right difficulty. Graphics are beautiful. Story is engaging and told in a very interesting manner.

My only minor complaint is the character controls felt a little stiff and sometimes dropping in and out of shadows (2D mode) was not quite as seamless as it needed to be.

Summary: Great game to play when you're inbetween games and want a pleasant distraction.

reviewText:
Disappointing for such a game that really could have been amazing. The general premise of the game, both story-wise (Didi and parents) and gimmick/mechanics-wise (using shadows to navigate and solve puzzles), was interesting enough for me to give the game a shot in the first place. I also enjoy the noir style and going back almost a century ago to a different type of world.

However, the game really let me down. There's just too many issues that all stack up against it, and the quality of the game seems to bounce back and forth as you play. The story starts off without much information, though I did get into it once I started picking up what was happening. But there are a lot of weird background details that are never explained at all, and nothing much seems to fit together. I also did not think there was much of a climax, and the ending of the game felt very cheap.

There is no real environment to the game, as the world is weirdly disconnected and with missing areas and emptiness. Basically, there is no life" to it

reviewText:
My suggestion: wait for a sale.

I feel so saddened that a game I have been tracking since initial release wasn't what I expected, at all. The concept of the overall storyline is interesting with the main character, Dawn, jumping between a shadow world and a 3D world. However, the game mechanics are sloppy and sometimes so bugged that it can ruin the game. At one point, the little girl, was a static figure and simply slid across the screen for an entire Chapter. Other times, Dawn seemed to hit this invisible wall when doing different jumping puzzles, making some jumps almost impossible to do smoothly on a first run.

The puzzles themselves were interesting and sometimes frustrating - which is always good. However, they sometimes would get so buggy...

My other main issue with the game was the general graphics of the shadow people. They were exceptionally blocky and I felt that the developers had gotten really lazy. I could see seams on forearms and their mouths never moved even if they were deep in conversation. I felt like they were more like puppets than people.

I also realized, after game completion, that there were significant plot holes surrounding some characters. I have no intention of spoilers, but it is really frustrating when a game feels incomplete in their storyline.

For the full price, it is not worth the four hours of gameplay. I highly recommend that you wait for a sale and buy it on a whim. I loved the concept, the voice acting (Jensen from Deus Ex anyone?), and the film noir style of both music and setting. However, between the bugs, the blocky animation, and the weak ending, I really felt cheated.

reviewText:
We should adress the good first, because what's good about this game is really good. The setting and tone of 1920's noir is brilliant and it shines through in every area; it feels like a mixture between the Sierra Madre and Bioshock's Rapture with the unique lighting, it is one of the best looking worlds ever seen in a game. Additionally, the voice acting is pretty solid and its interesting how you never see the side character, but you see their over the top body language in their shadows, which is quite entertaining in a Vaudville/Groucho Marx way. On top of all of this, the story is pretty good and surprisingly charming.

However, that's really the end of the good stuff. Like Limbo, contrast has a really good idea, but fails to do anything interesting with it past the very first puzzle.
Almost every puzzle is a varitaion of pressing a button to make something in the room move, which creates a shadow ramp.
Unfortunatley, there are two big problems with the shadow platforming, which is supposed to be the star of the show.
The first problem is that you will periodically stop being a shadow. You'll be standing somewhere and if you hit something (because shadows act like solid objects) you might instantly get out of shadow mode.
The second problem is that the platforming is pretty shotty with landing detection and there are times where it looks like you should be able to make it, only to clip through the shadow, meaning you have to start all over. This is especially problematic during the second act, where you have to climb a massive building using the shadows of a carrosel to climb a large rotunda. If the platform detection messes up at all, you have to start all over.
Additionally, there's an entire section of this game that is a direct homage" to Limbo. A section in which you run away in a dark shadowy world from a giant spider. This amounts to about 1/10 of the whole experience
date: which really shows that the developers were running out of ideas at this time.\n\nBecause of its incredible short length of about 3-4 hours
hoursPlayed: and its buggy gameplay I can't reccomend this as a game
voteText: but I can recommend it for its story and style"

reviewText:
Contrast is a 3D puzzle\platformer that takes place in a world full of magic, cabaret singers, and burlesque shows. It utilizes a 1920's 'French Noir Film' art style that is unlike any other game I've played. The character design is beautiful, the voice acting is amazing, and the jazzy soundtrack fits the world perfectly. I can't stress enough how much I love the look and feel of this game. Yet, I can't recommend it, which is particularly disappointing considering how much there is to like here.

You play as Dawn, a woman trapped between the worlds of light and darkness, and who cannot be seen by anyone except for a little girl named Didi. Didi's parents have broken up, and with the father out of the picture, her mother works at a nightclub to pay the bills. This, of course, means nobody is watching the little demon-spawn and it's up to Dawn to keep her out of trouble. Easier said than done, since she insists on roaming around the city at all hours of the night, refusing to listen to reason, and all you can do is enable her.

The entire game revolves around a shift mechanic that allows you to become a shadow, an ability you will need to solve puzzles and progress through the game. Adjusting light sources to cast shadows to interact with is this game's bread and butter, and you'll be doing a lot of it.

The problems with Contrast start almost immediately. While the puzzle mechanics are unique and interesting, they are a bit buggy, and simple platforming can be difficult with controls that don't feel tight or responsive. Dawn has a tendency to get stuck in the environment and other shadows as well. There are even a couple of places where dropping an object in the wrong spot could result in the player not being able to progress further, forcing them to load the last checkpoint.

Once the game defines the parameters on the first couple of puzzles, it doesn't change them up much and they can become repetitive fast, which really shouldn't happen in a game this short. Which brings me to the biggest issue Contrast faces. The entire game can be completed in under 3 hours, and the ending is exceedingly abrupt. All of these issues combined leaves me with a feeling that the game is unfinished. Almost as if Compulsion Games ran out of money for the title half-way through development. Obviously, I do not have firsthand knowledge that this is the case, but I can't shake the feeling that I'm playing an Early Access game, and not a full release.

Altogether, Contrast is a game that should have been a one-of-a-kind, beautiful experience. When a bad idea becomes a bad game, it's expected, but when something that starts off this amazing falls flat, it's all the more frustrating. I expected better, as did most gamers, and in the future I hope Compulsion learns from their mistakes, and releases games that shows us all what they're really capable of.

reviewText:
Contrast is a sometimes...frustrating game.  But ultimately rewarding.

The pros?  Where to begin!  Absolutely top-rate storytelling (this could almost be a film), sometimes ingeniously clever puzzles (though none so hard that one just throws in the towel), gorgeous graphics, wonderful sound, and a genuine sense of child-like wonder which seamlessly blends with the harsher realities of the adult world.  Think Tomb Raider meets Limbo (that is to say, both 3D and 2D platforming elements, effortlessly combined), with a story and direction worthy of Tim Burton (the earlier one, that one that made the good films before he became such a predictable hack).  Oh, and it's nowhere near as painfully LLLOOOOONNNGG as all games seem to feel the obligation to be these days (or in other words, it doesn't overstay its welcome").

Now the cons.  Some of the platforming elements are PAINFULLY pedantic...one teeny
date: tiny miscalculation in where you place a lighting rig (this game is all about shadows)
recommended: and you could very well waste the next forty seconds running and jumping to a point just to realise you ain't gonna make that final jump.  And then it's ALL the way back to the start of the puzzle again.  And there's some reflex-based moments of timing which become frustrating thanks to the sometimes ill-responsive controls
hoursPlayed: though fortunately

That we CAN'T necessarily invest two hours at a time into conquering A WHOLE FREAKING CHAPTER before switching off and going to bloody BED???\n\nBut as I said earlier...sigh...at least this is one recent game which doesn't feel the need to give us a non-linear plot full of extreme repetition

reviewText:
On paper Contrast seems like a really cool game: a puzzle platformer where you can switch between being a physical person and being a shadow on the wall, using the shadows of other objects to get where you need to go. Couple that with a jazzy nightlife setting, and you can't go wrong, right?

Unfortunately that is not the case. The platforming was often really frustrating and the game was fairly buggy. I found a few places where I could melt with a wall or I would have to jump three or four times to make it onto a ledge that was well within reach.

The story was alright. You play as Dawn, the imaginary friend of a little girl named Didi. Didi's parents are separated and she sneaks out in the night on a regular basis to watch her mother sing at a club. Dawn helps Didi to progress past obstacles and fix things, and hopefully eventually to reunite her family. Dawn and Didi are the only ones who appear as three dimensional people in the world; everyone else appear as shadows on the walls, and are often parts of the platforming that the player has to perform.

In a lot of ways I am glad that the game only took three hours. I wish I could recommend Contrast because it has the makings of a cool, unique indie game. But it just wasn't made well at all. Don't buy it.

reviewText:
The originality on display here makes up for the frustrating controls and lack of polish, JUST.  Whenever I came close to giving up because the dash is almost impossible to control, or in the bits that are simply constant-fail trial-and-error attrition, I was rescued by a fantastic mixing of game and story in ways I'd never seen.  The brevity of the game very much works in its favour and the concepts on display here are promising for future projects from this team.  More money and time, this could have been GOTY contender for me.  As it is, it's just really interesting.

I'd wait for a sale if length equates to value for you though, I finished it in 3 hours and I'm not eSports so you could probably do it in 2.

reviewText:
Great puzzle game with 3d and 2d jumping around figuring out puzzles, nice story and interesting characters.

That being said, not all shadows are created equal... or solid surfaces for that matter. There are a lot of places where lack of testing shows. Some floors aren't solid and character falls through, some shadows look like useable, but aren't. In some places you can't get into without apparent reason,  there is just an invisible wall in front. Controlling character is difficult at times, unnecessary pauses after cutscenes when character can't move. Shifts into above-view scenes where controls aren't clear and sometimes reversed, too small tolerances for wrong moves in these situations. If you walk in wrong way while figuring out controls, you are shifted back to normal view with a long pause in between.
Alt-Tab crashes the game 7/10 times... why? U3 engine does it so well in other games.
Hopefully these gets addressed, even if not in this game, perhaps in sequels or other products from authors.

reviewText: I first played this game in Target on the Playstation 4 as a demo, and found it to rather amuse me admist the staleness that consumed my soul as I waited my father to finish shopping for Theros knows what. It's a really low investment puzzle game that keeps you entertained with a really needy little girl, a weird family dynamic (like what's up with them being shadows), accurate and pleasant musiv given the time period it's set in, and well enough graphics that you won't rip your eyes out from the lack of. I haven't finished the game because I get bored of puzzle games after a bit, but if you do find the time, you should be able to beat it in a couple of hours and walk away feeling relatively pleased.

reviewText: A charming and relaxed puzzle platformer, Contrast features engaging characters and enjoyable gameplay. The story is broken up into three acts of roughly equal length, and is well-paced. While there are some interesting puzzles, the game doesn't feel overly difficult and thus the interactive elements won't disturb your enjoyment of the environment and narrative. The driving force of the game is definitely the characters and their relationships with each other. Overall this is a great experience and a solid, short game that I have already suggested to several people. The soundtrack and visuals are distinct and memorable.

reviewText: I first played this game in Target on the Playstation 4 as a demo, and found it to rather amuse me admist the staleness that consumed my soul as I waited my father to finish shopping for Theros knows what. Unfortunately, I at that time, and actually currently still do not own a PS4 and was not willing to invest in it for a single game....then I found Steam and purchased the game on there...eh here. It's a really low investment puzzle game that keeps you entertained with a really needy little girl, a weird family dynamic (like what's up with them being shadows), accurate and pleasant musiv given the time period it's set in, and well enough graphics that you won't rip your eyes out from the lack of. I haven't finished the game because I get bored of puzzle games after a bit, but if you do find the time, you should be able to beat it in a couple of hours and walk away feeling relatively pleased.

reviewText: This is one heck of a great indie game. The art style is simply amazing, the puzzle and platform mechanics are fun and innovative, the environment is very well fleshed-out and really gives character to the world. A nice heart-worming story, short and sweet but well worth the money if you want a taste of something that breaks the mold of all the popular adventure/platformer games out there. Just had a little trouble actually getting the game to run due to some game settings that don't allow certain graphic cards, but there is a quick and harmless workaround to get it going. Also forgot to mention the fantastic jazz and cabaret music that goes so well with the environment and greatly adds to the immersion into this world.

reviewText:
A 3D puzzle platformer that allows you to switch to 2D on lighted surfaces, many of the puzzles revolving around this ability.

The storyline is a fascinating scifi-noir mix, with a few loose ends that beg for a se/pre-quel. A lot of the detail is buried in the collectible documents throughout the game.

Length-wise, I finished the main storyline in about 3.5 hours played, and it took about another half-hour to get 100% on collectibles and achievements.

Beyond the collectibles/achievements, there is not a ton of replay value. I personally found the story intruiging enough that I can see myself playing through again at some point in the future.

reviewText: This is a game I recommend. However, at a low price. You're going to get about 3-5 hours depending on how you play and if you want to collect all the colectables. The game has a beautiful art design and the music especially the main menu music is heavely. The gameplay of going in and out of shadow is actually a really interesting one. reviewText:
The originality on display here makes up for the frustrating controls and lack of polish, JUST.  Whenever I came close to giving up because the dash is almost impossible to control, or in the bits that are simply constant-fail trial-and-error attrition, I was rescued by a fantastic mixing of game and story in ways I'd never seen.  The brevity of the game very much works in its favour and the concepts on display here are promising for future projects from this team.  More money and time, this could have been GOTY contender for me.  As it is, it's just really interesting.

I'd wait for a sale if length equates to value for you though, I finished it in 3 hours and I'm not eSports so you could probably do it in 2.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed playing Contrast, enough to farm all the achievements (a rare thing in my case).

+ Great idea overall
+ Excellent Atmosphere
+ Great Soundtrack and Artwork
+ Enjoyable Story

- Very short game (first playthrough took me less than 4 hours)
- Seems a little unfinished at times
- Puzzles are rather easy

I had a lot of fun playing Contrast and it left me wanting more. I could have done with at least another 2-3 hours added to the story though. It feels like the developers really put a lot of thought and love into the game but then got rushed to release it before it was finished. Would still highly recommend the game , maybe wait for another sale before picking it up though.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Stunning visuals. Beautiful soundtrack. Challenging puzzles. 1920s noir ambiance. A bit of carnival, a bit of burlesque. This game is full of art, music and beauty. There is no daylight – only streetlights that bathe the cobblestone streets and alleyways. You are in a dreamlike world. Straddling the physical world and the shadow world, you must use various light sources to carve your path in the shadows to the other side. Though all but two characters are mere shadows upon the walls, their voices echoing around you, the game manages to pull together an interesting and captivating story… a story that becomes an adventure for you, Dawn, and Didi - the only one who can see you. Didi wants her family back together, and you are here to aid her using your unique abilities.

At times, the gameplay mechanics are frustrating and glitchy. But overall, the game is challenging without being impossible. The puzzles are creative and clever, and they carry the shadow play throughout the entire game and encourage you to use it intelligently to either continue on your path or obtain necessary elements or optional collectibles. The immersion is consistent and flawless - you do not leave the world the developers have created until you quit the game. And even then, you may find yourself humming the theme song...

Though it will only take you a handful of hours to finish, it would be well worth your while to give this puzzle-platformer a try. This game has heart.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love games set in the 1920's. So, when I read that this one was set in that era and influenced by vaudeville, I immediately picked it up. In Contrast, you play as acrobat Dawn who is helping a young girl fix a series of problems in order to save her family. Throughout the game you visit a jazz club, circus, magic act and a few other fun locations to work through.

The atmosphere, world building, and overarching plot of this game are fantastic. It left me hoping that we'll get a sequel since I would love to be able to explore more of the shadow dimension.

This is a pretty short game (took me about 5 hours to complete the whole thing), but well worth a play through. Highly recommended.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
First playthrough time: 4 hours

Major Pros:
Interesting world, shadow people, and art style
Great 2D/3D combine puzzle mechanic

Minor Pros:
Interactable objects are highlighted well
Light sources for building your 2D terrain are easy to find and manipulate

Major Cons:
Easy to slip out" of 2D puzzles
Camera angles matter when dashing in 2D

Minor Cons:
For those interested in the collectibles
date:
you can't backtrack if you miss something
Puzzle objectives aren't always clear
Running in the 3D world sometimes feels too fast while walking feels too slow
Game textures and model polygons could've been a little higher res

The artistic world and 2D/3D blended puzzles are the big selling points of Contrast. The game has a solid 1920s feel complete with gangsters and big show biz. For some of the main story puzzles that are timed (you have to finish it before another character does something)
recommended: you can find out some interesting alternate-ending-esque information by letting time run out. The 2D/3D puzzles were my big attraction to the game. I think the concept is really great and the dynamic manipulation of the 2D landscape using light is pretty terrific
hoursPlayed: but a little buggy. It's unfortunately easy to fall out of the 2D world
voteText: particularly when dashing over anything slopped
helpfulPercent: and bumps in the wall itself can create unexpected shadows that'll knock you out into the 3D if you walk into them. I could see all these things easily being fixed in a sequel with better collision detection and a little more optimization of the 2D world. No unexpected weirdness was encountered in the 3D."

reviewText:
Such a fantastic game that really gets a lot of video game aspects right.

The concept is unique for a platformer, and the level design is actually creative and challenging.  There are points where you can freely manipulate the shadows in the world as you desire, which allows you to be creative in how you solve the puzzles.  THe voice acting is above-average, especially for Didi, and the character design is allows you to quickly relate to the main family.  The plot iself only really kicks up at the very end, but even so, the twist ending makes you feel warm and fuzzy inside after you've become so attached to each character.

There was a lot of love put into this game, and it shines through (pun intended).  Definately pick this up if you want a quick and fun game.  If you don't want to support the eight developers who made this game, buy it so you can see Kat's giant shadow-cleavage.

reviewText:
THIS GAME IS AMAZING! Now, it is quite short at around 3.5 hours, but if you missed some collectibles it can get you to about 4.5 hours. The concept of this game sounds quite cool, and in reality it is. The puzzles, at least for me lasted a bit considering I had to look up walkthroughs on half of Portal 2. I love the dual story line of this game! It deals with a young girls parents, and her friend" helping her through some tasks (hopefully that didn't spoil anything). The graphics are quite nice considering the location and time the game is set in. All in all a very enjoyable game for the $3 I paid for on the Steam winter sale!

+Great Puzzles
+Appealing Story
+Cool Gameplay
+Very Good Graphics For A 2013 Indie Game

-The Shifting From Shadow To Reality Could Be Improved.

All in all 9.5/10 for a stellar game!"

reviewText: Contrast is a game with a great core mechanic that makes for interesting gameplay and storytelling and works pretty well with the film noir atmosphere.  The story is mostly a generic film noir story that only gets interesting when it touches on the core mechanic, but the level design and puzzles keep the game interesting.  My only major criticism is the game feels like it was rushed—as though it could have and was meant to have had more content than ultimately ended up in it.  That said, what you do get is still a good experience, and definitely worth the price if you get it during one of Steam's numerous sales.

reviewText: Cracking little game, oozes a noir atmosphere, a little bit of surrealism and a little bit of science back when things like Tesla seemed unwordly. The game isn't long, a few hours will see you through the whole thing, but it's a rich and amazingly visual trip, with some clever platforming and puzzles that make great use of light and shadows.\n\nIf you want to see something innovative and an experience that doesn't come along too often, grab this game and give it a play.

reviewText:
Contrast is a rather simple indie, platform/puzzle game about a young girl, Didi, and her (apparently) imaginary friend Dawn trying to help out Didi's father figure, Johnny, over one single night in a 1920's, jazz-themed city
You take control of Dawn and are given the power to switch between a normal world and a shadow world in order to advance in the city, solve some puzzles and collect bonus items, like luminaries and plot documents. The premise is simple enough, but the game, while being worth just 2-3 hours of platforming and puzzle solving, is able to offer you a decent but fair challenge, introducing new mechanics and gimmicks as the story progresses that manage to keep you on your toes. Furthermore, failing a jump or anything of the kind won't inconvenence you at all, given you have pretty much infinite lives/tries
The  strongest points of Contrast are a very charming art style, which heavily borrows from the 20s and jazz music, and an interesting story, which is able to engage the player even if not exactly long or overcomplex. As mentioned above, there are some collectables to be found, but hunting them doesn't extend the game's lenght substantially
It's also worth mentioning that Didi, the young protagonist, is one of the most berable, cute and useful child I've ever met in a videogame

reviewText:
A short game with an interesting concept, contrast is a puzzle platform game based around lighting effects.

The story revolves around a child Didi and her silent shadow jumping imaginary friend Dawn, to whom you control. This game is rather mature and deals with many adult situations from day to day life. Set in a noir mid 1900's city, the ambient is that of night clubs, bars and cabarets. Most of the story events are told through the silhouettes of the secondary characters sometimes having the player be prompted to intervene.

All gameplay revolves around Dawns abilities. In shadow form she moves on a 2D plane where she can reach difficult locations and resolve puzzles, like taking a heavy object from the ground to a higher location made possible via the 2D shadows. Very rarely is the objective or next point of interest not made clear, but deviating from the path has it's own reward on finding more story elements, like memories of past events and collectables.

Sound is a positive, each location has its own themes and sound effects that plays really well with the way the narrative unfolds, considering that most the story is told via silhouettes the sound becomes rather important. Voice acting is pretty solid and old timey that fits the time period.

The game does end with a sort sequel bating, and unanswered questions, one of which is made right at the end of the game, which for me is a negative but not so much that I couldn't recommend this game.

If you like perspective puzzle platformers, early 20th century noir visuals and a bit of drama, I can recommend this game. It's not the most original game out there, but what it does it does well and certainly has its more charming moments that stick with you.

reviewText:
Contrast succeeds at being surreal and cute at the same time. Cute only because of the secondary main character and her naivity.

As a 3D platformer, it is very short, but boasts a wonderful art style that is also creepy in a Tim Burton kind of way.

You play as Dawn, an 'imaginary' friend to Didi, the daughter of Kat and Vincenzo. Didi's adoptive father is actually this guy named Johnny who's trying to make a name for himself. The overall story has overtones of mafia involvement, magic, illuisions, etc. It has a very early 1900's feel to it but the world is so surreal with the city that the game takes place being on floating islands. And the clockwork systems and other stuff.

The standout element is the ability to shift from the real world to the shadow world, similar to, I think it's Paper Mario where he can stick and travel on the walls. Or one of the Legend of Zelda's where Link actually does transform into a shadow of sorts. Well, it's like that. Dawn has that ability basically.

I guess my only complaints would be the lack of ambient sounds and the length of the game. Otherwise, pretty good.

7.5/10

reviewText: A unique experience, however brief, that should not be passed up by anyone who's looking for a good story. The game is presented with a beautiful art style in a strange and enchanting city, where you play the role of an imaginary friend looking out for a girl named Didi. On your way you'll solve puzzles, shift into a dimension of shadows and explore the dimly lit city.\n\nIt wasn't long before I knew that this would be one of the best games I've ever played. I can remember many games that might have a more satisfying conclusion, better structure and pacing, but Contrast is simply beautiful and engaging, and I could never stop to wonder why. It's a game that's been made with heart and soul, by developers who really wanted to share their vision and story with the player. And although it may not have been fully realized, Contrast is a simply marvelous mystery that I'll be recommending to my friends.

reviewText:
Short, but not too short

Contrast tells the story of a little girl named Didi and her seemingly invisible friend Dawn, who is literally living in the world of shadows. The story is set sometime in the 1920s and takes place in a wonderfully crafted and stylistically consistent world that looks like a mix between reality and dream.

You as player take on the role of Dawn, who is not only invisible to everyone but Didi, but can also shift between the 3-dimensional realm of reality and the 2-dimensional plane of shadows, where ever there is a bright light on any large enough surface. The feature is well-implemented, and most of the puzzles are cleverly built around this feature; the way it forces  the player to view things and think about them differently reminded me of Portal 1 and 2 - in a good way.

The story, surprisingly, is far from being a fairy tale for children as there are some very dark tones to it. On the other hand however, Contrast is a fantastic example for a compelling experience that does not need unnecessary violence in order to work. Both gameplay and story work well together, and neither falls short.

Speaking of short, the only short thing about the game is the time it takes to complete the story; for me, this was less than four hours. This is not to say the game is too short, however, as I found it to be just the right duration for the story to unfold. Any longer and it would've fallen into the same trap as so many other games that try to stretch the length of a decent story by diluting it with repetitive gameplay segments.

So can I recommend this game? Yes, the story, gameplay and presentation (both visuals and audio) are definitely worth it. However, if you are unsure because of the short length you may wish to wait until it is on sale again.


On a sidenote: When I started playing the game with a DualShock 3 Controller emulated as 360 Controller using MotionInJoy, the camera seemed to be a little oversensitive. After changing to a proper 360 Controller (cable) for the second half of the game, the camera seemed to be a little more controllable. Just a heads-up for everyone using a DS3.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Short but sweet. Contrast is a very creative game, unlike most of the games I usually play. While it has its share of flaws, i.e. gameplay feels clunky here and there, it totally makes up for it with surprisingly interesting characters and fantastic music. The game is short, and the end left me wanting more, but despite some frustrating moments, I just finished it with a satisfied feeling. I was really rooting for Johnny to get his act together, and I think, most people will. I got Contrast for a nice deal (during the Canada sale), so I'd really recommend you spend a few euros or dollars if the game is up on sale again. It'll be worth it.

Here come the buts":

- Animations are a little strange/cheap

So if you're aware of that and want to spend an evening in a 30's jazz scenario:
Wait for a deal."

reviewText:
A good and enjoyable NOIR-like platformer game but a bit short in my opinion, you get to play with imaginary friend (female protagonist) of a little girl and help her to reunite her family (the plot twist in the end is really well done).
-graphically it's really nice and well done with the unreal engin, got that 1920s french noir feel.
-the gameplay is smooth and fresh, you have to solve puzzles by shifting between real 3d world and 2d shadow world but sometimes it gets on the nerves cause you gott be quick .
- no bugs or glitches and crashes , at least for me .
-you got 25 easy achievements and some cards to craft a nice badge
-the only thing that i disagree with is the price of the game , 14.99$ is a bit too much for a short game ( around 4 - 5h to finish) and asking 19.99$ for the Collector's Edition that contain the soundtrack and some infos about the game (except for the soundtrack , the artwork and infos are pretty much mehhhhh).
i recommend this game for puzzles loving gamers

reviewText: This game was nice , but sadly a bit disappointing. When you see the trailers and read about it your in awe of an act where you can influence the stage. An act by the great Vincenzo, a casted illusion of a large scape platform game. The game is horridly too linear, pretty straight foward you just need like 4 lumis and the game progresses for a short time before suddenly coming to the ending. I was saddened as I was expecting more depth, more platforms and more plot. The game is visually appealing and did have an amazing idea,just failed to execute on it unfortunately. If your looking for a good long enjoyable game I would reconmend not buying, its not even worth its discounted price(and I bought the Collector Edition). I do hope the designers of this game understand the meaning of platformers,2d/3d, story and the most important thing gameplay, not Ideas cause thats all I saw and it went to waste along with my money.Good story and graphics though.

reviewText:
This is a game I was interested on since it was in GreenLight, and one of the few games I've pre-purchased (afair it might be the only one). I finished it a long time ago, but my first pre-review was not complete so here I go:

Contrast is beautiful (very beautiful) at both graphics and OST (as long as you like jazz music), original in its gameplay and not too long but neither too short (though an additional chapter would have been welcome).

The negative point I would mention would be about some few - very few - animations and textures that could have been improved, however being an indie and, afaik, the first game of the studio, I think these little sins can be forgiven.

But the main thing I really don't like, though is not about the game itself, is that even having pre-purchased it and existing no special edition at that moment, now I find that there is and that contains the OST (which I'd like to own), but with no option at all to upgrade to... imho this is not a very nice way to reward the ones that believed in the game (and no, iTunes is not an option to me).
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Presentation
Contrast is one of those games that's unique and memorable at the same time, as it drags you into a shadow world in the 1920s Paris in the role of Dawn, young Didi's best friend who possesses the ability of shifting between the 3D material world and the 2D shadow world, making Contrast one of most ideas-filled titles of this year. Didi is also the only person who can see Dawn, but the actions you perform around the city will have an impact on the real world that is seen as shadows from Dawn's eyes as well. Even though Dawn is an interesting character on her own that you'd definitely become interested in as the game goes, this is the story of Didi's parents, who are constantly arguing after Didi's father left and her mother is too busy working at night, leaving her unattended - a perfect opportunity for her to sneak out and fix things around the city with Dawn's help. The bad thing about Contrast is that it will end too soon, rushing through the events of the story just to get to the ending, and even though following the plot is satisfying as it is, there are lots of moments that could've been detailed more, making the game longer and the lasting experience more satisfying in the end. Without doubt Contrast nails its presentation, having a simple menu that will almost instantly take you into the action, while still offering you plenty of options to manage things such as collectibles or taking a look over your stats. Starting with the purely astonishing art work and the detailed characters and moving on to the shadows that have an important role in the gameplay, but offer an incredible visual effect as well, the game is constantly reminding you how awesome its core idea truly is. The problem with that idea however is that it hasn't reached its full potential, as the moment when you get most comfortable with the control and the idea of the game is the same moment the game will reach its denouement. There are so many ideas that are simply rushed inside the game, such as walking up the shadows of Didi's parents in order to reach a location and listening to their speech while doing so; those are the kind of moments that make Contrast feel unique and make you desire more out of this game.
Rating: 9.5

Gameplay
The idea of shifting between the real 3D world and the world of shadows is without doubt one of the most unique and innovating ideas of this year and Contrast takes great advantage of this idea, creating some amazing puzzles that will leave you satisfied each time you complete one and move in to the next area, but the best thing about those puzzles is their deductibility, forcing you to analyse each one of them, but offering the solution if you stare at them long enough as it is sometimes more than obvious. Each new location you visit will introduce new puzzle concepts, some trickier than others, but same as the story those are rushed, never taking full advantage of their potential, as the game will quickly move from one concept to another, leaving abilities such as the shadow dash to be used only a few times in the entire game. There are the occasional glitches that will stop you from making a move in your first try, but there isn't any sort of time pressure on the gameplay so you have all the time in the world to find your way around a puzzle and reach your destination. The 3D world puzzles are enjoyable and the shadow puzzles even more, but the real magic begins when the game combines those elements to create some amazing areas that you will have to scout first, try different approaches and only then decide on a final solution that will take you to your destination, but all this time spent looking around an area is well spent as you will constantly be excited about where one thing should go or how the positioning of some objects will help you reach a higher point. Walking up the shadows of Didi's parents is an amazing concept as you get to listen to a part of the story while you're slowly making your way to a location that's related to that story, constantly keeping you on the edge about what's gonna happen next as you climb higher and higher and eventually reach a location that will unlock further mysteries. There is a lot of great stuff in here and because it is so great it leaves you with a thirst for more and unfortunately there isn't anything else.
Rating: 8.5

Graphics
Contrast on the PlayStation 4 looks amazing, making the city of Paris come to life at night with the use of those same shadows that make the gameplay so enjoyable, as the little bit of light that is available in an area will reflect objects in the precise direction, something that affects the gameplay as well as the overall beauty of this title. Even if you only get to see Dawn and Didi as full characters, as the rest of the cast is seen as shadows, they are both incredibly detailed and fit into the world perfectly. The visual effects are okay, with a few things that could use some work, but what is really impressive is the reflection of certain things on the pavement of the street as it is wet and seeing that no matter where you go is impressive.
Rating: 9

Audio
The voice acting is top notch, as the entire cast including Didi, her parents and Vincenzo take advantage of some amazing voice work that truly helps sell the story and the emotional road it takes once you get to know Didi better. The sound effects are just as good, making the world come to life and give Dawn's powers a great background; the best thing however, comes in the soundtrack, as from the start of the game you will be greeted with a noire classic, a perfect fit for the city of Paris in the early '20s, and the list goes on and on as you progress through the game.
Rating: 10

Extras
Unfortunately, the main campaign is the only thing that the game provides and that will be over in less than 6 hours, depending on how much time you take to solve each puzzle, and even though the game has collectibles you can find those easily in your first playthrough if you just look around, so unless you wanna replay the game a few weeks after just to relive the awesomeness, there isn't anything else to keep you around.
Rating: 4

Verdict
Contrast is one of the best experiences you can have this year, not only because it is unique, but because it works wonders, providing some great puzzles, amazing exploration and a story worth hearing, unfortunately that will only last a few hours, so if you were looking for something to keep you around your PS4 a lot more, this will come as a disappointment, but either way Contrast is a game worth playing at some point, even if it isn't your priority for the new console.
Rating: 8.2

Check out the full review and a lot more about Contrast at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=38&t=330

reviewText: Disclaimer: I have mostly good things to say about Contrast, but the lack of polish on this game makes it so I simply cannot recommend it, no matter how much I wish I could. A post-release patch could easily fix all the issues I describe below, but two years after release and these are still problems; hence, thumbs down, albeit reluctantly. I was tempted to grab this game when it was first released, but I'm glad I waited. I completed the game in about 3.5 hours, so do the math and figure out what amount of money you'd be willing to pay. I would instead recommend a game like Papo & Yo, which also centers around a child with family issues and is of similar length with equally unique but different qualities. So, without further ado:\n\nContrast is a platformer where you shift between the 3D real world" and the 2D "shadow world" to solve puzzles. The controls are clunky/sloppy and you cannot remap your keys. This game was released in 2013 and the player can't remap keybinds? Hell

reviewText:
I'm glad I didn't buy it at its full price, because even though there IS GOOD in it, the good is not enough to justify the cost.
The concept is stunning, great atmosphere, the soundrack makes me wanna drink tea while smoking my pipe wearing an early 20's nightgown and the shadow/real world switching is such a cool idea. Also, I'm in love with Dawn even thought not much is said about her.
BUT (and here comes the ugly part) how could they develop her character when they couldn't even properly tell the whole game story? Let me be clear: the story has a beginning and an ending (which I adore because I hate when they leave you puzzled) but it's told in such a rush you won't really find yourself connected with anyone. This game is short (or better: it would be but as I'm gonna explain next, it will gain longevity thanks to all the times you're gonna uncontrollably fail).
There is something really wrong with the controls, I played with a controller and Dawn's movements were very uncomfortable. I tried using mouse and keyboard and it was kinda better but still, weird physics. It's not very reactive and considering you have to jump a lot and switch while rushing and jumping, that's a big no no for me.
It got on my nerves, I fell so many times and had to run back and forth so much that I almost threw away the controller.
Gotta be honest, I insulted Dawn so much that if she were real, she would have come find me and punch me.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
After beating the game, I can say that I don't find the game fun. Sure, the visuals are beautiful and the music is good. The morphing into shadows is a cool game mechanic  however too many times in the game is it easy to slip out of the shadows or something will knock you off. Sometimes jumping on to platform becomes tedious work, you end up concentrating on to getting on to one platform so much it takes away from the beauty of the game and its concept. I find myself fustrated  more often then not, and when I'm not I am a little bored. Plus after a while I did get annoyed that the child was consistently bossing me around.

SPOILERS DOWN BELOW

As for the story, it's hardly there. So you're Dawn (the tall shadow girl) who is the companion of Didi (little girl) for whatever reason Didi and you are friends, or at least Dawn feels a sense of responsiblity towards Didi for unknown reasons. You sneak out at night to see her mother perform in Act 1. In Act II, it concentrates on helping Didi's father figure because its clear he owes the mob money and he is using a broken cicrus to get money to pay them back. Then in Act III, Didi's biological father is performing at the circus and Didi ends up following him to his workshop in hopes for some connection. Then in the final act you have to turn on the lighthouse to light up the stage where the biological father is performing.

Then in the ending there's this big happy dysfunctional family scene where mother takes father figure back meanwhile biological father offers Didi a chance for them to connect too as family. Keep in mind through out the whole game Didi and Dawn are the only 3d people everyone else is a shadow on the wall. The biological dad morphs into a real person and places his hand on Didi's shoulder, she gasps exclaiming she thought Dawn was the only one capable of that. The last scene is the biological father thanking you (Dawn) for taking care of Didi.

Prior to this point if you were looking through the collectables, its set up to make you think Didi is mentally ill and that we are playing as some imaginary friend or demon/fairy. So its an interesting twist because it does change your perspective on what the story is. Because we are never really given the whole story most of it is for the player to piece together and make decisions. And in the end, you don't know who Dawn is as a character, or whiy she has a relationship with Didi, you don't know why the biological father can morph in and out of shadows or while he knows Dawn, the question of why is everyone a shadow expect for Did is never really answered.

There is one collectable that is a old time picture of Didi being a shadow on a street of real people, which could suggest she's the true shadow person but then it goes into hay wire with what occurs in the game.

If you still want to play after reading this be my guest, I just feel that the take away from the game wasn't impactful enough to make my eariler fustrations worth the trouble.

reviewText:
I was very disappointed with this game. I wouldn't say it's bad, but pretty much everything felt underwhelming or out of place. You would think that in a puzzle platformer the platforming would be really fleshed out and feel good, but in reality it's super clunky. Even the 2d bits once you enter the shadows feel bad and bugy. The dashing ability makes no sense. Why would the players character be able to do that. Maybe if it was just for platforming and mobility, but you are braking fences with that ability. It's just silly. Same goes for the players ability to carry big boxes like they are made of cardboard. As game mechanics they are fine, but they don't feel right in the games world.
Considering the length of the game I think it could have benefited form just flushing out the basic platforming and shadow stuff and leaving out all the other tiny mechanics. In my mind having a solid platformer with a shadow gimmick would be much better,  than a clunky platformer with a bunch of flimsy mechanics that are used only handful of moments in the game. Moving objects to manipulate shadows was very interesting, but again, it was used only two times in the game and wasn't all that sophisticated. It would be so cool if the game had a bigger emphasis on this aspect.
The story is nothing special either. It's very simplistic. I really didn't care about it. It was frustrating that the mystery of why only the players character and Didi have physical bodies is addressed only at the very end of the game.
The only positive aspect of the game is its aesthetic. The Art Deco/cabaret stile is relay cool. And some of the level design visually is very interesting. Though I was a bit disappointed that in a game about shadows the shadows them selves ware a bit ugly at places.

In conclusion - get it on sale if the screenshots look really tempting to you, but stay away if you want super tight gameplay.

reviewText:
A game built around a couple good ideas--setting, shadow mechanics--and not much else.

The gameplay the entire scenario is built upon can, more than anything else, be described as simply glitchy. It bugs out constantly, leading to unfair deaths or do-overs. Some puzzles, like Vincenzo's workshop, are absolutely agonizing because of this.

The setting is nothing more than an idea: Cabaret. That's it. Nothing more.

The developers seemed to have desperately built everything in this game on those two ideas, turning them into nothing more than gimmicks. The story is nonsense--a mash-up of heart-felt cliches and sexist family drama the player will not care about, with random (--wrong--) references to Einstein and generic ideas of science floating in the background. I guess it's meant to add depth to the universe they're creating, but it doesn't help when a handful of the world-building collectables are called nothing more than Science Drawing" and are literally just nonsense symbols and images.

The story also just gets in the way: I can't count the number of times I'd move a few feet and have control taken away from me
date: so the camera can do a stilted
recommended: early PS2-era swoop over the surroundings
hoursPlayed: complete with lots of janky start-stop moments. Speaking of
voteText: the controls--movement and camera--also feel like the platformers (e.g.
helpfulPercent: MDK 2) of the early '00s.\n\nWhatever. Everything wrong with this game comes from its creation. It's clear the general ideas of the shadow mechanic and gimmicky cabaret setting were steps 1-10
votesHelpful: and everything else was an afterthought."

reviewText:
9/10

Amazing artwork and concept. Very nice music, story and voice acting. Some jumps can be a bit tedious, especially toward the end of the game. Except for timing of some jumps, I had no issues with controls. No complaints about camera movement either. Length is perfect (I like short games). Overall, a unique game that’s well worth your time and money. Highly underrated.

BTW, the save system is limited to milestones which are quite far apart. This why I just left the game minimized between sessions and the reason for the longer than usual game time. I estimate it was about 4 to 5 hours of actual play.

Pros

An incredible looking world that brings the 20's jazz/circus noir look into a hibrid dream/imaginary world, a great gaming concept with a lot of potential for fun, compelling and complex puzzle solving and an interesting plot with the potential for plenty of depth, growth and heart breaking/warming scenes was not nearly enough to save this buggy overly simplistic and mindnumbingly dull game.

reviewText:
To put it simply, Contrast is a game that follows a little girl through her beautiful, broken world.

In Contrast we take on the role of Dawn, the imaginary friend of the character Didi- we go on an adventure with this little girl who is trying ever so hard to just put her family back together.

Contrast features a wonderful Jazz soundtrack that really brings a lot to the game as a whole. The voice acting is full of emotions in both the English and French translations of the game. The voice acting is well recorded and well cut. 5/5

The visuals in Contrast are some of the best to come out of Greenlight. This near unique art style really gives the game some flavor. Contrast has top quality visuals both in it's 3D, and 2D worlds. I have yet to encounter fuzzy or broken models/textures. 5/5

The story is brilliant and the execution is just as wonderful. Though many complain that the story is too short" we need to remember that length does not dictate the quality of the story. Contrast's story is about bringing a broken family back together. The story has all elements of a story
hoursPlayed: and an interesting conclusion. Watching the world change as the story progresses is simply fantastic. 4.5/5\n\nMechanically
voteText: Contrast has a few issues- though the game does contain a brilliant feature where the character has to work through both 2D and 3D worlds

votesHelpful: the gameplay is relatively choppy- whether the character will execute commands correctly in this state is hit or miss. We can regularly see the character pop out of the shadow world for no apparent reason what so ever. This is not game breaking
votesTotal: but does cause some frustration when attempting more complex or multi-step puzzles. 3.5/5\n\nI believe that this game could also use some optimization with the keyboard/mouse. For me
votesFunny: it was a little tasking making the settings work with my hardware. This has no impact on the final rating.\n\nFinal rating – 18/20 or 90%   - I would suggest getting this game."

reviewText:
The game's title perfectly encapsulates my play experience, which alternated between delight and frustration. The story follows a young girl named Didi, and so do we. We step into the shoes of a mysterious young woman called Dawn, who assists Didi on her quest to mend her broken home. The story is generally well executed and the art style and music help sell it beautifully. Steeped in early 20th century vaudeville aesthetics, the game's mood is warm and magical, but the over-the-top theatricality often seeps into the dialogue, at times causing it to come of as trite rather than impactful.

The main conceit of the game is that Dawn exists in a sort of parallel world, and her only connection to the real world are Didi, who seems to exists in both worlds, and the shadows. Dawn has the ability to literally become a shadow on the wall, and most of the gameplay revolves around using this mechanic to solve puzzles and execute jumping challenges. Shadows are also the only way in which Dawn can see people besides Didi, and the game's most inspired moments combine moments of shadow-puppet storytelling with actual gameplay. Unfortunately, these moments are far and few between, and most of the challenges are fairly mediocre, with the shadow-shift mechanic adding little but a bit of flavor. My biggest disappointment is how often the game interrupts the flow of gameplay with little cutscenes, sometimes wresting away control of your character simply to execute a camera pan and deliver a line from Didi.

The game shows great potential, but falls short in execution. Aside from the issues already discussed, there are the occasional technical issues, such as graphical glitches, erratic collision detection and at times wonky controls. A more rigorous synthesis of gameplay and storytelling could have elevated this game out of its mediocrity. However, its charming style and rare moments of inspiration make it worth a look should you find it for cheap (e.g. during on of Steam's many sales).
