reviewText:
A great platforming\puzzle game for people that are not into such.

If I were to categorize players as follows Type1: Rarely plays video games or sticks to Iphone type of games Type 2: A regular video game player, but not into platformers/puzzles Type 3: A regular video game player and is into platformers/puzzle games and type 4: A diehard fan of platform/puzzle games.

I would say that Contrast is for the Type 2 player, which is where I classify myself. The graphics and sound are excellent and the story is interesting, but the challenges are not over the top. I play games other than platform/puzzles, like RPGs, survival, action, shooters, etc, but the look and story of Contrast intrigued me so I got it and finished it (only took 3.5 hours) and it was a great experience. The difficulty was right up my alley and I felt good about resolving the puzzles.

The voice acting, sound, music,etc are all excellent. I normally detest games with 'collectibles' and will usually ignore such in games, but in Contrast the collectibles were easy to come across and, towards the end, they really open the story and shed some light (pun!) on the background of the character you are playing, Dawn.


Overall I would rate this game pretty high, say 8 out of 10. Especially because it is so short, I can see myself playing it again a few months from now.

Edited for typoes.

reviewText: This is one of the most well-imagined games I have ever played. The art style, the concept, the characters, the storyline, the soundtrack; everything is phenomenal. I was drawn in instantly. Unfortunately, I found it a bit difficult to stay immersed at times. The gameplay is quite buggy. I'll admit, it has gotten better than it was the month after release, but I still feel like it could be better. Interacting with items is difficult to initiate and rather imprecise once you do, making some puzzles a bit more difficult, not to mention frustrating, than they otherwise would be. Another minorly infuriating aspect was the save system. You cannot manually save. The game saves automatically after solving certain puzzles or reaching a crucial plot point. The problem is, you never know which puzzles it saves after unless you're paying close attention to the corner of your screen. I was so fed up with having to do certain parts over that I abandoned the game for weeks at a time several times. All of that being said, I still truly enjoyed the game. The positives definitely outweigh the minor glitches and I am recommending this game to everyone. And who knows, they may fix the save system and wonky item interaction at a later point.

reviewText:
Some nice ideas and visuals, but there's really not much to it. The game is quite short which is fine, but for a puzzle platformer there are very few actual puzzle/platform sections. And some of these can be more frustrating than fun due to clumsy controls, poor guidance, or just long waits for cut scenes (especially in the shadow puppet/princess part).
Although the game world looks quite nice it feels very empty (although maybe this is the point) and you have some freedom to wander around but there is nothing to do or see until you are forced to go to that area later in the game.
While not a bad game per se, unless you are looking for a short indie platformer reminiscent of American McGee's Alice with an interesting mechanic poorly executed, I found it to be dull and tedious and you are better looking elsewhere.
There are far more enjoyable indie puzzle-platformers out there worth spending your money. See Two Brothers, Deadlight, Trine, Braid, Limbo, Thomas was Alone, etc...

reviewText:
Maybe I'm just too quick to be critical of games, but sometimes you have to be in a world with hundreds of thousands of video games and lots of Triple A titles.
For me, Contrast is the type of game that delivers a game mechanic that promises to be innovative and amazing, but fails to really deliver where it matters - namely, being able to use shadows as though they were tangible things. You start off as an unnamed woman walking around in a little girl's bedroom, and it is quickly conveyed that all living creatures (with the exception of one special little girl) appear only as shadows and you are invisible to one-another.

Unfortunately, after establishing that you are this little girl's friend (by way of picking up a drawing she made with you in it), that's all the reason you are given to follow her off on a boring adventure of interacting with objects, collecting objects, and being pestered to do things and go places in order to watch cutscenes. It really feels like it's being forced upon me when I don't even want to follow this little stranger and watch her parents fight; I want to explore the world and be given my own reason for doing things instead - not because a child tells me to.
So that was storytelling ruined within the first 5 minutes.

Then there was the shadow mechanic - it seems cool in theory, but you end up using it to do very rudimentary platforming straight off the bat. Exciting stuff. Maybe throwing a few shadow balls would be nice, or knocking over a bottle, or knocking over a bottle's shadow using a ball's shadow! The first few minutes are where you really have to give OOMPH to this new mechanic, and sadly it's used only to run up shadow ramps (some of which are inaccessible until you have tagged along with your new friend so she can push a simple object for you and progress the story). Again - I'm feeling like this is off to a bad start. I hear the game eventually progresses to pushing boxes around, but manipulating an object to reach a high place is hardly an innovative improvement.

And finally there's my last gripe - atmosphere. At one point within the first 5 minutes you also walk into a cabaret restaurant which is completely devoid of people and life. BUT WAIT
date: you say, people are invisible and appear as shadows!" Well yes
hoursPlayed: but there is nothing to make this restaurant feel LIVELY. There are glasses of alcohol on tables and cigars smouldering away in ashtrays
voteText: and there is ambient audience music playing
helpfulPercent: but there is nothing to make it feel ALIVE. No swaying and sliding of chairs
votesHelpful: no sloshing of alcohol
votesTotal: no strange poltergeist-esque atmosphere replete with drinks trays floating around the room; bartenders shaking tumblers and pouring them out
votesFunny: no cats in alleyways knocking over trashcans and yowling
commentsCount: certain conversations that dim and fall as you wander the room - there is nothing - and that is where this game really falls flat on its face. You walk into a dead room and your only objective is to interact with the flashing objects scattered around the room so you can progress the plot because an invisible woman keeps nagging you to turn on the lights.\n\nI'm sorry
column16: I wanted to like this game
column17: but it took 5 minutes to convince me that I hated it - all because there was nothing to try and persuade me into staying a while
column18: looking around and really enjoying myself.\n\nMaybe somebody somewhere else will do it better one day - because this game isn't there by a long shot."

reviewText:
The idea is nice but... it quickly turns out that this is not a brain teaser but a horrific jump'n'run in the 2D world.

Although for most of the riddles it is easy to figure out what to do one has to play the same sequence over and over again until he gets the correct sequence and timing of buttons to press to accomplish a task.

Additionaly the controls are completely messed up (read the forum!). You push the left lever up / the girl runs backwards. Pull it down and it runs forward. The game tells you to push the X-Key but expects the Y Key / same with A- and B- Keys.  Same with the keyboard: Push W to run backward. Unplayable!

The Controls are so messed up that you easlily loos all your progress without any warning. No way to select a scene to get close to where you've been.


This quickly becomes very frustrating.

If your looking for a way to waste your money this game is for you.
What a disappointment :(

reviewText: Contrast is a great idea that is never expanded to the fullest. The aesthetics are delightful, the puzzles are challenging and fair, but the game is far too short unless you're going for every last little objective. It's an engrossing story for what little there is. I really wish I could recommend this, but this game only lasted me a mere 3 hours in total. This game needs some DLC missions or some other expansion. It's too clever and beautiful to leave things as they are.

reviewText: Contrast (video game) is a noir atmospheric puzzler set it in the 1920's. You play as Dawn, the imaginary friend to Didi, a 9 year old girl who's step father is trying to put together a circus. Throughout the game, you must help Didi help her father put on a good show.\n\nYou morph in and out of the 3D world and 2D world of shadows, helping Didi by solving various puzzles. The gameplay was okay, there is a little bit of weirdness with the camera, but it wasn't too bad. It's a lot of parkour but the puzzles were pretty simple. The majority of what makes this game so good are the music, art and it's story. If anything, it's what makes the game worthwhile. Should be a quick and easy finish and will make for a good afternoon session.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
TL;DR: Check it out.

THE GOOD:
• Gameplay:  Contrast is a truly unique concept; I can't think of anything that does something similar: shifting from a 3D environment to a 2D one using the shadows on the wall.  Shadows can sometimes be manipulated by moving light sources.  It's neat!
• Story:  The story isn't masterfully told, but it is an interesting one, and I'm glad I stuck around to see it through to the end.
• Art:  Contrast is beautiful to admire and its music is always a pleasant companion.
• It's Indie!:  Support your local indie game developer!  Especially when they're doing awesome work like this!

THE BAD:
• Game Feel:  As cool as traversing the shadows as a platformer is, Contrast has a tendency to be real finicky.  On some puzzles, I would get so frustrated falling out of the shadows, I would question if I was performing the task correctly; in every case, I was.  It becomes easy to slip out from the 2D world and fall to your death, and not even be sure why it happened.  I managed to finish every puzzle, but I would have had a lot more fun if the mechanics had been fine-tuned a bit more.
• Acting:  The voice acting could've been a little more convincing, but--  Ehh! What'r'ya gonna do?

reviewText: I started tracking this game back when it was on Greenlight, and it looked amazing back then. It took me some time to start playing it after it was released, but I'm glad to say that it is actually pretty neat, with very interesting and novel mechanics, with a cool story behind. It can be beaten pretty fast and I would actually recommend doing it. The bad parts about the game are: excessive guidance on what you need to do, every cinematic shows you exactly where you need to head, let me explore a bit! Almost all achievements are all very easy as well, with no need to go back to previous chapters once you finish the game to get them.\nI recommend it, but would really like to see the same mechanics developed better in a more polished and longer game, with challenge rating up a bit.

reviewText:
This is the second worst kind of indie game.
The worst kind being cheap ripoffs of whatever's popular right now (see: zombies, survival, crafting).
This however is an overly artsy fartsy platformer with one single original idea - which cannot carry a game by itself.
In the first hour or act you gain no understanding of your agency or place in the world and you begin to realize that you never will. The game just is way too much in love with its imaginary-friend-perspective of storytelling.
And what do you do? Follow a linear corridor of boring puzzles. Yes the shadow walking gimmik makes them orignal, but the shallow world, fixed camera (starting in act2!), and dodgy controls really remove all joy that might have been had here.
Oh and the Soundtrack" are 15 tracks that amount to 20 minutes of samey music - and it's not even in FLAC format.
Not even worth 5 bucks.

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, believe me, I do.

I adore the music and the unique art style and the story is interesting, but the gameplay is so infuriatingly difficult at times that it breaks the immersion and makes me not want to play it.

The shadow shift ability is very sensitive. If you run into something, or if you're crushed by something, you'll shift out of the walls and you'll have to try again or you just might die altogether. Not only that, but it's very easy to miss jumps when you're trying to jump over certain gaps (most are easy to scale, but there are a few that are just mind boggling). And there are also some puzzles in which you have to reach a platform in a small amount of time - and those kinds of challenges in games are always maddening.

I'll play and I'll be mesmerized by the details and I'll want to find out what happens next in the story but then I reach a roadblock of a challenge and - after being pushed out of the walls, failing to jump over gaps and dying repeatedly - I get increasingly frustrated and then it's not about the story or the gameplay anymore, all the focus has shifted to that one piece that just doesn't seem to give if you don't get it just right. And after all is said and done and I can move on, I just can't relax and enjoy the game anymore and have to shut it off. A game is something that you should be able to enjoy and crave, but if it's frustrating - there's no point in trying; and that's a real shame.

It's a good game if you're a big fan of challenging puzzles; but if you're looking for a fun game with a sense of ease and flow, you might want to find something else to try.

reviewText:
Overall Score: 8/10
My advice: If you like a good puzzle/story driven game, buy it.
Genre: Third person puzzle platformer

Contrast is a short, sweet, stylized adventure with an intriguing story and a fascinating concept. It only took me about 6 hours to finish the game with all achievements, so don't come looking for an exceptionally long playthrough. The story it tells is worth experiencing nonetheless.

The story follows a little girl named Didi and her mysteriously invisible friend Dawn, who you play. The girl's mother is a singer at one of the local clubs, giving Didi a chance to sneak out at night and try to learn more about her father, her family, and ultimately, the origin of Dawn. As Dawn, you have the special ability to enter the walls around you, walking atop shadows to help Didi during her strange and dream-like adventure.

As you can imagine, there are quite a few puzzles to keep you occupied, but not as many as I would have liked with such a fascinating concept. The music is fantastic, as is the stylized atmosphere, but what really ties things together are the story. Almost the entire story is told through the shadows and the things people leave behind, and they still manage to craft an interesting arch for it all. If I had to complain, though, harder puzzles would have really made this game a lot more fun, and the occasional frustrating glitches shaved off a point in my book.

Still, for this kind of price tag, it's a crime not to pick it up.

reviewText:
A small indie game that is not only great to look at but also being played.

It has two unusual leading characters - a young girl accompanied by an adult woman -, is set in a rare environment (France 1920s) and always tries to reward you with a snippet of story after you complete a puzzle. Puzzles get repetitive after a while as in any platformer but it doesn't manage to reach the point it gets bothersome as the game isn't that long, circa 6 hours without chasing collectibles and occasional hiccups. I haven't encountered any bugs (W7, i5-2400, ATI HD 6870 1GB, 8 GB).


If you like Braid, chances are you will enjoy Contrast too.

reviewText:
Contrast is a puzzle platformer in a 1920’s themed setting, featuring a young girl named Didi and her friend Dawn.The game starts with Didi sneaking out of bed and into a nightclub where she finds that her family life is not quite as perfect as she hoped. You play as Didi’s mysterious friend Dawn, and must help with her journey to repair her broken family and get her parents back together.

From the title screen, the scene is set wonderfully with a jazz soundtrack and noir design looks great. I have always loved the style in games such as Bioshock and the individual locations ooze of it, from jazz clubs, to cinemas and hotels, they all look the part.

Your character, Dawn, can move between three-dimensional reality and into the shadows where the game becomes almost like a 2D platform game as she is limited by the shadows on the walls. Light sources create shadows and can found placed in areas to reach a platform that is too high to reach. So for example, if Dawn needed to get to an outside balcony in reality, she could enter the shadows, and now reach it by traversing shadows of a nearby café tables and chairs. that are on the wall.

It is a clever idea and on the whole it does work very well but I found that despite learning new abilities along the way such as being able to dash through shadows, the gameplay mechanics start to feel samey and predictable. It usually involves reaching an area which is inaccessible in reality, reach it in the shadows, and then activating a switch or cutscene to progress. One puzzle which stood out was the final level which involved some great use of lighting and platform/puzzle elements that offered a bit of thought. There were one or two occasions where I was not even sure I completed the puzzles as the developers intended, as it felt to me like I had taken a shortcut to completing what I imagined a more difficult puzzle.

The story is told well and without spoiling it, the game follows Didi’s mother and her troubles with her husband. The husband gets himself mixed up with the mob, and while his intentions are good, things do not go well for him and he lands himself in to more trouble the harder he tries to fix things. If you explore the world a little, you can find snippets of story which act as mini-puzzles while you listen and in ways interact with as you jump over the shadows of the characters or events.

The gameplay can be a little clunky at times. I was reviewing the PC version and played the game with both keyboard and controller. The controller felt very sensitive to small amounts of input and it occasionally made me fall off platforms or do something I did not want to do. The camera can occasionally give you trouble but it is free-aiming and can be fixed. The most annoying aspect is that I managed to get stuck in walls and scenery on a few occasions, with no option other than to restart from the last save position.

The length of the game should also be put into question. It took me just over three hours to complete the game which I found was very short. There are collectible items to find over the course of the game but you will find many of them on your first playthrough. There is little to keep you coming back after completing the game. I would have liked some more puzzles or side quests to add some lifespan and replayability.

Don’t get me wrong, I enjoyed the game a lot. The characters are likeable, especially Didi who reminds me of Clementine from The Walking Dead game. The story is interesting to watch unfold and interact with. But there was simply not enough puzzle content to get really stuck in to. It is worth pointing out that Contrast is free on PlayStation+ and in this case it is a must play. If you are a fan of the era or platform/puzzle games then you will enjoy the game, I would wait for a sale otherwise as it is a little too pricey.

Gameplay - 7/10
Clever use of reality 3D and shadowy 2D platform elements, but is let down by occasional clunky controls and finding yourself stuck in walls.
Graphics - 8/10
Lovely 1920's noir style locations and design set the scene perfectly.
Sound - 8/10
The main theme tune is perfect for the game but there is not much else to listen to that is memorable. Character dialogue is done well.
Final Score - 7/10

reviewText: As someone who followed the development of Contrast with much anticipation, going as far as preordering it on steam, it pains me to say that the game is not good. What looked like a fascinating premise in a fantasical world intermixed with an amazing sound selection turned out to be only one of those things. Being a shadow becomes very boring very quickly, as the puzzles all end up revolving around a convulted system of controls that will leave you very very frustrasted. You will be afraid to enter walls. You will be afraid of messing up a button press. And you will be very afraid when you realize this puzzle will just continue to drag on with more complicated situations that faulty controls will only make worst. The only puzzle game I can think of right now that followed the same tune as Contrast is Braid, and by Jove does Braid make this game look like a joke. In Braid you can rely on your platforming abilities to carry you through a series of increasing difficult puzzles, which will truly reward the player for their abilities to think intuitively as well as perform proper platforming practices. In Contrast, you will struggle about a world with frustrating controls, little variation in puzzles, and little reward from solving the them. Little reward as in you will not care at all about the story because your willful suspension of disbelief will begin right at the start. The game takes place in France, and it makes a point to say so. What it doesn't explain, unless I understood world history entirely incorrectly, is that the world is floating in a vacuum of space. No explanation ever. No explanation as to why Didi, the girl you are escorting most of the game, sees the pit once but never comments on it again, as well as no one else commenting on it. Hell, in my opinion, the characters stopping to talk about the fact they live in a void would be more interesting than any plot point presented in this game. The story is weak, from the first moment of blackmail to the ending scene. The ending won't make you feel anything. You will be annoyed by Didi. You will hate every character that pops their ugly mug in this game. So what do you have so far? A messy universe with messy controls, a cast of completely unlikable characters, a character that is a young annoying child most of the game (Trust me, Didi is no Clementine, and you will go back to hating video game children after playing this,) in a story that is riddled in plot holes and does nothing to keep you interested in it. Oh, but the music is pretty at parts. I think I heard some of it over my continued groans over having to do another jump dash puzzle that would randomly throw me out of the wall to my death. Do yourself a favor, and skip out on this one.

reviewText:
If you are into Jazz, Contrast is worth playing just for the sake of the soundtrack.

If the premise of a bluesy, gloomy, artsy, early 1900's Paris atmosphere - which this game reflects brilliantly - doesn't particularly appeal to you, you might want to think twice.

Contrast's gameplay is entirely based around blending 2D and 3D, a good idea; fits well with the semi-magical atmosphere, but unfortunately doesn't feel like it's been used to the full potential. The biggest challenges lie in the 2D platformers, whilst the 3D part feels underexploited (and the keyboard controls clunky - this was clearly designed for a controller). The 3D world just serves as an aid to model the 2D world, or as a link to reach the next 2D surface. At some moments, you feel like it's almost there and regret what the game could have become if the 2D and 3D had been made to blend in a bit more crazily.

Some of the puzzles are brilliant, some of them just about mediocre, but it all ends too soon. The game is extremely short (only 3 levels, count about an hour each). WIth no extra difficulty or challenge, with all collectible lying out in plain sight of the linear path, the replay value relies on just one thing: the really compelling atmosphere, characters, and the excellent voice acting.

reviewText:
Contrast is the differences seen when two sources of light come together. Similarly, Contrast (the game) blends its ligher and darker tones into a short, immersive experience with differences of quality that feel worthy of the price of admission, yet lacking in other ways.

If anything is holding Contrast back from feeling complete, it's not just the gameplay itself but also the technical issues and the final act.

This game will ultimately feel like it was two-thirds of the way done but never half-baked.

Dancing in the Dark
Contrast is by no means a difficult game. Your average playthrough, depending on how many collectibles you go for, will take you somewhere from two to four hours.

(I would strongly recommend going for the luminaries as they use the shadow-swapping mechanic a lot, which is the main attraction for this game.)

Games like these with a narrative focus are fine. Sometimes games with little to no challenge other than my wits are relaxing, which this game never struck me as being overly complicated.

However, the inclusion of replay value would have been appreciated as well besides tying up the loose ends of the plot.

In Contrast, you play as an imaginary friend of the main character of the story, Didi. As you are a make-believe creation of hers, you are a surreal character to the mature events unfolding around you.

This also means you are given supernatural abilities: The ability to swap in and out of shadows and the real world, the acrobatic fitness to traverse the environments, and a few other abilities (a dash mechanic and  the ability to use light orbs). The main focus is always put on the shadow-swap mechanic, which I think is its best quality.

You aren't simply finding the well-lit areas to enter and leave new entrances. You are moving light-sources to shape the shadows on the environment, enlargening them and scaling them down, and you sometimes have to use the shadows' terrain to move real objects.

Sometimes the technical limitations rear themselves into this mechanic, such as when you are going around corners and you might teleport out of the wall because of not rotating the camera. Or when you enter a wall with the camera on the other side of the wall. For the most part, this mechanic is well-thoughout and only at some parts of the game feels buggy.

Unfortunately, the other gameplay aspects either feeled tacked on simply because other platformers have them or they are there because of the game's light/dark theme.

The acrobatics shown on the first trailer on Steam are nowhere to be found in this game. (I watched it after I finished the game, and I felt that was worth mentioning because of how misleading they were.) I think the game could have benefited from more twitchy swapping sections lacking in the final game without making the game have a sudden difficulty spike. It would've also made the open-areas more expansive and well-worth finding the collectibles.

The luminaries only feel necessary when the plot demands it, and there are more than enough within the area you are locked in to never worry about finding any more. In the end, I felt these were pointless other than for achievement purposes.

The Shadows on the Walls Tell All
The one thing Contrast nails almost flawlessly is its narrative format told through gameplay. Although the game deviated from what my inital expectations were--of a subconscious friend being there to aid the protagonist--I still appreciate the manner of the story told that is not too dark for kids and not too forced for adults.

Do not write this game off as another tale of the loss of innocence. That's not what the game is about; it's about seeing the adult world through a child's eyes with an imaginary friend.

The adult themes of vice, regrets, misfortunes and personal mistakes make the world intimidating while hiding away the faces and other details that would make things more clear.

Characters other than Didi and Dawn are represented by silohouettes with distinctive voices and models. The side-cast are executed well, and the implementation of their cutscenes as platforming puzzles" is an interesting way to keep the pace of a game going. This is a case where a limitation on the budget ultimately proved to be a great outlet for storytelling purposes

reviewText:
When I first heard about Contrast I immediately remembered the old PC platformers with gorgeous graphics. I then pre-ordered the game to get my hands on the illustrations and art that inspired the game. I couldn't wait to play the game.
Disappointment is the word to describe what came when I finally got the chance. You play as a shadow character for a good part of the game and the graphics of the shadow-world are really unpolished to say the least.
There are some annoying bugs on the puzzles that hinder playability and kill the atmosphere of the game.
I don't know the studio behind Contrast but the game seems the result of amateur work and is miles away from other good platformers available on Steam.

reviewText:
This is a very pretty game, with a great atmosphere, strong gameplay that has very few flaws. Sadly the game falls short on story and character development, as well as length. There are really only about 3 big areas to explore, and although the puzzles in those areas are fun you feel you want MORE.  The music is also very good.

If you are okay with the fact that Dawn never talks and most of the plot mysteries are barely hit upoun and never even partly explained, and all you want his is eye candy with decent gameplay, then this game is worth buying at this price (14.99)

If you want more but are still interested, I would wait until the price drops by half at least. I don't know the reason why they took out the original murder plot and dective Dawn helping Didi solve the murder and save her mother/family, but what they but in place of that plot is pretty much junk.

The gameplay time you will get out of game is 4 hours. But seasoned platformer gamers will likely get even less.

reviewText:
So this game turned out to be quite enjoyable even though it is unfortunately very short. You play Dawn a woman with the power   to shift from the 3D world into the 2D shadow world. Also Dawn can only be seen by her young friend Didi who also happens to be the only person Dawn can see as everyone else can only be seen as a shadow.

The game is a pretty decent puzzle platformer, with a mix of 3D platforming and 2D when you shift into the shadows. This mechanic makes for some good puzzle sections as you need to shift in and out of the shadows to complete them. The visual style of the game is great as well with a sort of 30's noir vibe to the world Dawn and Didi inhabit, as well as a decent soundtrack to match.

The biggest problem with this game is it's criminally short. I was left wanting more at the end and it really lets the game down.

The Good:
- intersting mechanic of shifting from 3d to 2d to complete puzzles
- this game looks pretty good with a 30's Paris look to it
-a good jazzy soundtrack that really adds to the feel of the game.

The Bad:
- Very short and i was left wanting more
-Little replay value

Overall this is a pretty good game which i enjoyed but it really is too short to justify paying full price. If it's reduced on offer and you like puzzle platformer pick it up. 6.5/10

reviewText:
I would have to say Contrast is one of my favorite games. The art style, music and time setting are right up my street and the whole game takes place in a slightly surreal 'Alice In Wonderland' style. I'll explain. The world seems to be made of of floating islands floating in a night sky, it looks lovely but detracts the game from normality, that being said playing as an imaginary friend who can jump in and out of shadows ins't exactly normal so this floating island surreal-ness actually adds to the game, pushing it away from normal and closer to dream-like.

As I have said the music is also fantastic if you enjoy cabaret style music. There are also some lovely other tracks later in the game, one of my favorite plays during the carousel puzzle.

The whole jumping between shadows and normal world is an awesome mechanic. Not exactly new but it is still nicely done and it creates some interesting and genuinely challenging puzzles that stumped me for an embarissingly long time. One thing I will say is that it can be a bit trickey at times. The switching between the shadow and real worlds is tricky especially when jumping. If you don't time it right when jumping you will land half above, half in the shadow which gives you another 50/50 chance of clipping onto the shadow or being forced back into the real world which will probably spawn you into a death pit. After 6 or more times this gets annoying. The run animation is also odd too and the main character moves like she has a rocket attached to her back and strides like the Striders from Half Life 2.

Aside from those 2 tiny nit picks the story is good, visuals great and soundtrack fantastic. Pick it up, play it and you'll be glad you did.

Check out my youtbe channel for lets plays and commentary every Monday and Friday
http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2l1zwMcpJm_hJq4owO3nHg

reviewText:
This game does the biggest crime of game design repeatedly -- it takes control out of the player's hands.  REPEATEDLY.  NONSTOP.  You get a cool puzzle time and you do it and then CUTSCENE and you can't do anything but listen to a single mom fight with a deadbeat dad in the shadows on the wall then it takes like 3 seconds to give back control to you.  First it zooms in on the back of your character all cinematic pan-camera style when all you want to do is move.

God it's frustrating as all hell.  It's a cool mechanic, being able to turn into shadow.  But it's badly done.

Don't waste your damn time.

reviewText:
Damn two way system...this would've been neither a thumbs up nor a thumbs down but a middle ground. It has some strong points, as well as some lesser ones. I'll see if I can post it without one to get around that pickle.

The strong points sort of sells itself on the store: the visuals and the ideas. Oh, and the voice-acting and the audio.

Theme-wise, this is a wonderful film noir kind of feel with the old stylish drama and some genuinely fitting soundtracks that perfectly fit the gameplay mechanics. Climbing the shadow of the musicians or the voice actors while they are acting their part is original to say the least. As well as having the far majority of the cast consist merely of shadows (which gives the game a strange atmosphere).

Unfortunately, while the gameplay is certainly fitting with the theme, the switching between 3rd person adventuring and 2d 'shadow' platforming doesn't quite mix that well. Despite the contrast in lighting, you sometimes have to guess where you can fade in the shadows, and sometimes you almost randomly drop out again. And rearranging lights in a 3D plane is a lot harder to properly 'aim' than in a 2D one (for those who are familiar with A shadow's tale: control was much tighter there).

I'm not so sure what to think of the plot. While the atmosphere, voices and visuals are all in place, I wasn't drawn into the game much. I partly blame the clunky controls and some glaring bugs (I encountered numerous invisible walls and pass-through walls), and partly because the far majority of the game you're just a nanny for Didi (let's fix this! let's fix that!")

reviewText:
A short, but unique adventure platformer with seamless switching between 3D and 2D shadow-sections. While it's mainly linear, some areas allow you to create your own path of shadows to walk on. Storytelling is cute and enjoyable, and on top of that, it's often a direct part of the game because - once again - of the shadows.

I liked it despite the port being quite poor - almost no proper options in the menu. It's an Unreal Engine game, so the standard ContrastEngine.ini tweaks and some driver-forced AA will fix most of the bad looks and make it the superior version of the game. Of course, it would be nice to have these in the menu, as the game clearly supports them, but it's an indie developer and the game is enjoyable enough that I am willing to forgive them.

All in all, well worth 5€.

A charming story set in a beautiful environment.  The concept and mechanics of this platform game are innovative and fun despite the clunky controls.

reviewText: This is a good game with a mechanic that is reminiscent of the Shift games, which I think did it better. It could be because I played them first, or because I found the 3D to 2D in Contrast imprecise at times, which made some of the jumps pretty frustrating. It was also sometimes unclear how to set up the environment to successfully get yourself where you need to go, but I actually enjoyed how freeform these parts were and would have liked to see more of them, with a bit more polish.\n\nI really did like the atmosphere and setting, though I don't think the whole shadow idea meshed well with the rest of the game, and the locations felt more like they were pieced together based on how interesting they would be to play through instead of being used to create a cohesive narrative. Despite this, it was a very charming game with some interesting puzzles, and is worth picking up on sale to satisfy your curiosity.

reviewText:
When I saw the trailer to this game I was immediately drawn in. The concept of using shadows was new and intriguing. The game is quite beautiful and the scenes are fluid and well put together.
That was the good, now for the bad.
The controls are clunky and when all is said and done, it is still a rather standard platform puzzler. A handful of actually clever solutions aside, they are mostly jumping puzzles that require you to push a button to solve, or just time the shifts appropriately.

Even with that, the game is fun. Which to me is what matters the most.The few puzzles that surprize you don't take terribly long to sort out, but you feel like you did something when you do. There are clues that hint at a sequel, I myself look forward to picking that one up as well.
At least a 7/10

reviewText: I highly recommend this game. I really enjoy the way the story is told as well as the unique gameplay mechanic requiring the player to traverse shadows. I am a big fan of the film noir atmosphere and the soundtrack is quite enjoyable. I have found myself listening to it outside the game as well. Seems to be a fair amount of gameplay for the price. Not too sure about replay value though. 7/10
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a wonderful game.  The story and music are really well done and the characters are incredible - if you are nostalgic for the big band, gumshoe era, this game is right up your alley.  Loading it is a little tricky as you will likely need a patch, but once you get it working there are very few hitches or problems.  The game play is unique with you playing a character that moves in and out of shadows and helps a little girl find her way in the world.  Most of the puzzles are fairly straight-forward and are somewhat portal-like in their layout.  I was able to solve most without assistance.   It is not a super long game but creates characters you will cheer for and love.  Gets a little metaphysical toward the end but doesn't attract from the story.  Definitely worth the price - not sure why such a lower metacritc score - was certainly better than a 66
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Has some troubles with mechanics, which can get a bit fiddly and annoying at times, but overall I was really pleased with this game. It had great characters, environment, voice actors, and you can clearly tell that it was a labour of love. The story is interesting and sucks you in, and while the ending is quite ambigious and leaves me wanting more I can't help but love this game. The idea of shadow jumping and making use of 2D environment was really creative and I like that the developers stuck to that idea as much as possible - it made things unique and interesting. I know I have my fingers crossed for a sequel.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Very beautiful game visually - especially if you love the whole 1920s look and feel. The puzzles can be challanging at times, and you'll probably fall to your death a lot in the later Acts because a shadow decided it didn't like you anymore and pushed you out. If you're a more experienced puzzle solver you'll find this game a little short (I finished in about four hours, without hunting for all the collecitables).\n\nThe music is wonderful to listen to and I didn't find myself growing tired of it at all. And I love the fact that you get the soundtrack if you put out the extra couple of bucks. I did find myself wondering if, for the lenght, it was worth the $20 but the visual look and music made it worth it to me personally. Overall a very fun game and I wish it had been longer, if only so we could explore the lore of the world more because it seemed like there so much we didn't get to learn, even if Didi's story was over. (Granted I am a bit of world-building and lore nerd.)

reviewText: This game is gorgeous, with great music, settings, story and some cool secrets as well. There are some stiff movements from character models at times, but nothing that should detract anything from this game. Well worth your time and money.

reviewText: An interesting concept with promise, that sells itself short. The light puzzles are interesting and for the most part straight forward. The storyline is entertaining with a few nice hooks but also fairly straight forward. The art style is a unique with an abstract 20s themed world. The soundtrack including voice acting is very good. The game lacks some final polish to the controls, interactions with the environment and can suffers from occasional random frame drops reducing game immersion, which leave it as only a good - very good game/interactive story. This is a shame because the game had potential to be amazing. Worth picking up, even though you can finish the game in 2-4 hours. The developers show great potential, I look forward to their future projects (just remember that final polish to your game makes a world of difference)

reviewText: I got a new computer, so I decided to try out Contrast as my first game. I couldn't stop! It was a lot of fun - not too challenging, interesting storyline. Wonderful graphics, audio, and characters. It was shorter than I expected, but I enjoyed it a lot and really hope for a sequel. I am sick to death of fighting games, so a game with no fighting at all that was still fun, interesting, and different was a very pleasant change of pace. Its replayability isn't /too/ high, since once you've figured out the puzzles, it's easy to breeze through, but I would play through again simply because it was fun and I loved playing. All in all, I would very much recommend this game to anyone seeking a new game that's challenging, but not to hard, without any fighting, and a great soundtrack.

reviewText:
E=MC²

It's commonly accepted as one of the most elegant and yet profound discoveries of science. There are equasions which Mathematicians and Physicists say put a smile of delight on their faces and which they describe as beautiful. That may seem odd, but they understand the complexities of these acadamic arts and therefore percieve how hard it is to produce something simple yet powerful. For anyone who has an interest in game design - you will have the same reaction to Contrast.

The game is elegant in design, form and presentation. Simple in concept yet profound in its scope and it is a genuine shame that the idea of moving into a world of shadows and back out again hasn't really been explored much in any form of media; be it literiture, movie or gaming. If there was ever a game that deserved a sequel it would be this one. We're talking about the kind of simplicity and genius as when someone said; Lets make a game about wormholes and using them to solve puzzles. Contrast is as unique and creative as Portal without any shadow of a doubt, if you'll excuse the pun.

At it's core it's about puzzle solving, but there is a bit of a storyline in there as well. Although it isn't fleshed out much. The setting itself is the very distinctive Paris of the 1920's but with a weird blend of 20's America as well. I won't ruin the surprize but you'll start to understand that something isn't quite right with the world when you start wandering around the streets. As for the level of difficulty, it isn't too taxing. But the variety of gameplay and novel use of moving into shadows is constantly compelling. This is a short, but perfectly polished gem of a game which is well worth a look.

As an aside, the game can be played with either a pad or the keyboard and mouse. I would suggest using a pad because when using the keyboard there is a weird 'floaty' feel about movement which feels wrong. This may in fact cause frustration, as a number of more tricky platforming sections of the game would be made unpleasently awkward if you use the keyboard and mouse. Once you use a pad however, the controls are rock solid and precise.

reviewText:
An Amazing Masterpiece
I am impressed. No matter what your major gaming genre is, I think you will like this brilliant example of contemporary game art design. Also, not hardware hungry: Runs smooth here, on a mediocre notebook (Dual-i5 and GeForce 610M).

Requires some timing & control skills though, but that seems doable to me, so far.

An option to remap the control keys (incl. mouse) would be nice, which is missing. Experienced users may want to edit the ContrastInput.ini which can be found in ...docs/My Games...

reviewText:
For those of you who enjoy inventive platforms, or dynamic interestings story lines I highly recommend this game.

Contrast brings to the table inventive gameplay with well crafted characters. As the story develops your emotions run with it a bit, and it makes it that much more fun and interesting.

The collectibles bring extra elements to the story you wouldn't have known otherwise, so even if there wasn't achievements for finding them, they tie into this story extremely well and answer questions you wouldn't have even thought to ask. In fact, in Act III my mind was basically blown because the ending wouldn't have made any sense if I hadn't found every collectible, and after the first collectible, I wanted to know more so I made sure I grabbed every single one before the end of the last Act.

The ending makes you want more! I won't tell you any of it, but I personally was blown away and left awaiting a sequel.

But for those who worry about how the game handles, Its controller compatible and easy to pick up, and for those dedicated to the key board and mouse it can't be very hard to manage. It ran smooth and I didn't have to change any settings for it to work and faster. I was very satisfied in that regard

This group does an amazing job, I not lay in wait for a sequel, but for their other projects as well. I can't wait to see what other inventive ideas come next.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewerDisplayName: s a m s o n
reviewText:
Contrast is a highly ambitious game which just falls short of being amazing. The gameplay is unique and interesting given that the game allows you traverse between the real realm and the shadow realm which greatly changes how the player would interact within the world compared to a game which is just in the third dimension or just in the second dimension. While the puzzles are integrated nicely within the world you are placed in, the game is rather short taking me just under four hours to complete the entire game.

The aesthetics and charm of this game brings back the feeling of a platformer back from the Playstation One era, however the game often has issues explaining the story and world to the player which is mainly due to the game being so short. However if the player is keen on collectable hunting, collecting as many as possible can give some very interesting and subtle insight onto details the story does not wish to make obvious.

The voice acting feels stiff sometimes and often repeats itself, more often than not having the child explain to you where to go despite you already knowing where you have to go. However the voice actors in themselves are believable and well done, each reflecting the character nicely.

Despite being a short game, 15USD is not a steep asking price for what this game offers if you are looking into a unique platformer. That being said, I would recommend waiting until a sale since 15USD can buy games with a lot more gameplay.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Its very pretty and the core mechanic is quite unique.

You got some 3D platforming but mostly youll be jumping around in 2D - inside..on (?) walls, as a shadow, using shadows cast by objects as platforms. These arent just static either but will move and often you can change their position by moving lights in front of objects or vice versa. You can shift in an out of them and take crates and stuff inside and then manipulate those shadow objects with spotlights for example. Impressive stuff.

It is however shockingly short, 4 hours at max. Kinda feels overpriced but thinking about it you really couldnt slash the asking price down more than would amount to about 2 coffees and a bagel or the like, so...

But for those who worry about how the game handles, Its controller compatible and easy to pick up, and for those dedicated to the key board and mouse it can't be very hard to manage. It ran smooth and I didn't have to change any settings for it to work and faster. I was very satisfied in that regard

This group does an amazing job, I not lay in wait for a sequel, but for their other projects as well. I can't wait to see what other inventive ideas come next.

reviewText:
Its very pretty and the core mechanic is quite unique.

You got some 3D platforming but mostly youll be jumping around in 2D - inside..on (?) walls, as a shadow, using shadows cast by objects as platforms. These arent just static either but will move and often you can change their position by moving lights in front of objects or vice versa. You can shift in an out of them and take crates and stuff inside and then manipulate those shadow objects with spotlights for example. Impressive stuff.

It is however shockingly short, 4 hours at max. Kinda feels overpriced but thinking about it you really couldnt slash the asking price down more than would amount to about 2 coffees and a bagel or the like, so...

reviewText:
PROS:
Story - the writing and voice acting in this game were great
Novelty - introduction of an innovative game mechanic that lends itself well to creative and challenging puzzles

CONS:
Controls - movement is awkward and occasionally a bit frustrating
Unpredictable triggers - Use key on the wrong item and you will be taken to the next part of the story before you've had a chance to try and find everything in the current level
Length/Price ratio - This game is a bit expensive for being so short. Totally worth picking up on sale though.

Many people complain about glitches but I didn't see anything too obvious. There are some kind of annoying places where you fall through decorative parts near the edge of the level that look like they should support you, but you'll only notice this if you are off exploring. It won't impede progression through the actual game content.

Don't expect this to be game that's going to help hone your precision platformer skills. The controls, collisions, and physics are too wonky for that. The puzzles, story, music, art, writing, etc. however, are all very well done, and very cohesive. Nice little game.

reviewText:
Background: Was attracted by the striking 'French' visuals and intriguing gameplay that put me in mind of the film and game of 'City of Lost Children'.

The Good:
* Oozes atmosphere with elegant visuals and design
* Ingenious light based mechanics
* Sound design is pitch perfect in all aspects
* Cutscenes are brilliantly incorporated
* A mature story that draws you in as it unfolds
* Plays well with mouse and keyboard despite the very consoley feel

The Bad:
* Some (rare) glitchy mechanics spoil the flow
* Gamespeed/movement feels too fast on high powered machines
* Too short (4 hours) and you want more

Impressions: I was strongly put in mind of the films of Jeunet (like a cross of 'City of Lost Children' with 'Amelie') and was impressed at the inventiveness of the puzzles and that the developer resisted repeating themselves just to pad out the game. That said 4 hours will be enough for a run through and another 1 to pickup missing achievements.

Some have criticised the game for not answering questions but the answers are all there if you listen, read the clues you collect and join the dots in your head.

Recommended for: Puzzle fans and those who like ingenious but forgiving platformers.

Conclusion: 9/10. Charmed me and tugged on my heartstrings from start to finish, just wanted more of it.

reviewText:
Set in 1920's Paris; the City of Lights is an ideal location for a shadow based puzzle platformer. Consistantly testing your perspective of lighting and which dimension you should be within. The game adds an interesting 3D world aswell as a constant 2D platformer which you have to vary between in order to complete puzzles. Having the power to slip between the open 3D world to hopping from shadow to shadow in 2D at your own will opens up some very clever puzzling possibilities.

Throughout the game there's a gripping emotional story line in which follows the main little girl, Didi. As she is always trying to help out her close-to-useless father, having to deal with various mobsters, aswell as an illusionist puzzle master. As Didi’s imaginary friend, you can only see the shadows and hear the voices of the real people within the 3D world, in which Didi interacts with. But again within the 2D world there is great interaction of the real people's shadows and a fulfilling sense of achievment once you complete a puzzle.

As with all medium to low budget puzzle games there are a few bugs/glitches but nothing you can't turn your head at. Some of the puzzels can be very cliche: move a box over a button = door opens. But there was a few interesting ones you'll have to think twice about.

Overall gameplay was enjoyable and certainly made you want to finish the game, yet only being 3-5 hours long depending on collectables and the narrations. It’s hard to say whether Contrast looks better while playing as one of the minimalist silhouettes or running around in full 3D. The graphics are a key aspect of the game, being set in such a hearty destination the overly cartoon design looks great and is consistant throughout.

8/10

reviewText:
Contrast is a unique 3D platformer (2D when you're in the shadows). I played it some time back so I cannot write out an exhaustive review, but suffice to say the setting, story, soundtrack and voice-acting were all decent here. The artstyle especially was unique though. The game mechanics are interesting, but they were never fully fleshed out. The puzzles are mostly of moderate difficulty, but one or two of the later ones might frustrate you for a while.

The game is a bit rough around the edges with texture pop-ins, some wonky animations and some other minor control bugs. The ending felt a bit rushed for the story. Length wise, it is pretty short at 3 hours or so, and you should be able to 100% the game in around 4 hours.

If you go in with your expectations in check and manage to get this game on a discount, I'd be pretty certain you'll come away liking it. At least that's how I saw it in the end - a unique game that did not overstay its welcome.

reviewText:
Here are the cliffnotes of a review I wrote for this game elswhere:
I’ve had this game on my Steam wishlist for a few months now and decided to grab it during the Winter Sale last week. I’m glad I did because, in retrospect, I wouldn’t have wanted to waste more money than I already did on it.
This is not something that I would call a puzzle game. A puzzle implies that there is an intricate mental test to perform that has a rewarding outcome if you can find and place all the pieces. To solve the puzzles in this game you just have to perform trial and error because there really is no intuitive puzzle to be had. You platform around as a shadow on the wall to perform an arbitrary task and that’s about it. The “puzzle” aspect comes in, I GUESS, when you turn a wheel or press a button and the shadows move and you continue platforming. Maybe it’s that some of the buttons are on timers? I suppose some people would consider that a puzzle……But if you find those people, please, remind them to take the plastic bag off of their head once in awhile.
Bottom line: I wouldn’t recommend this game unless you have a big hard-on for platformers….But there ARE better platformers…..Much better.
I’ve played about an hour and a half of the game and I’m over half done. I just simply don’t see any point in prolonging the review. I’m probably not even going to get around to finishing this game.

reviewText:
Is this game worth your Time? That really depends what you're trying to get out of it.

As a game I think Contrast falls flat. The controlls feel unnatural, the shadow thing feels like a gimmick, the puzzles are uninspired and the only challenge is rooted in the poor controls and a camera programmed solely to avoid the angles that you actually need. That said, the soundtrack is fantastic, the graphics, especially the character models, look like something from a Tim Burton stop motion (in a good way) and the story is compelling (that's not the same as good)

In the end Contrast won me over. I feel the aesthetics win out over the gameplay shortcommings. Wait for this to go on sale and definitely shell out the extra couple bucks to get the collector's edition for the soundtrack.

reviewText:
8/10

Cool game with pretty graphics, great and atmospheric music, a unique gameplay mechanic making for fun puzzles, and a neat little story. Only rating it an 8/10 however because of bugs and other issues (note: my computer exceeds the recommended requirements and played the game fine on high settings). At times, Dawn will slide around at high speeds or suddenly stop moving due to some invisible obstruction. That's annoying while walking down the middle of the road, but downright frustrating when trying to solve puzzles, especially while in shadowland. These movements sometimes cause Dawn to shift out of shadows at inopportune times as well, requiring restarting entire puzzles. The worst issue, however, are the occasional times when something that is supposed to sparkle (such as an item that can be used or a collectible) does NOT sparkle, and thus can't be used. Collectibles don't stop you from completing the game, but the usable items not sparkling certainly will. I was able to solve this issue by restarting the game, but it's still annoying and meant lost progress.

All in all though, I would still recommend Contrast.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Though visually stunning and in employ of a very interesting game mechanic I'd never seen before-- the manipulation of lights in order to traverse through a shadow-world to allow the player access to areas that are otherwise unreachable,-- I felt that these two points were not enough to make up for the amount of glitches and the weak plot that I found in an otherwise palatable game. For the amount I bought it for, I felt this game was not polished very well, and it certainly doesn't help that the secondary character you follow was written in a very annoying manner. Noir games are often hit-or-miss because of the amount of stereotypes the genre builds upon, and Contrast followed the routine noir atmosphere and plotline.\n\nIn short, this was a very imaginative game, but I don't see myself going back to it for another playthrough. I would recommend it for the shadow/light manipulation, however.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
8/10

Cool game with pretty graphics, great and atmospheric music, a unique gameplay mechanic making for fun puzzles, and a neat little story. Only rating it an 8/10 however because of bugs and other issues (note: my computer exceeds the recommended requirements and played the game fine on high settings). At times, Dawn will slide around at high speeds or suddenly stop moving due to some invisible obstruction. That's annoying while walking down the middle of the road, but downright frustrating when trying to solve puzzles, especially while in shadowland. These movements sometimes cause Dawn to shift out of shadows at inopportune times as well, requiring restarting entire puzzles. The worst issue, however, are the occasional times when something that is supposed to sparkle (such as an item that can be used or a collectible) does NOT sparkle, and thus can't be used. Collectibles don't stop you from completing the game, but the usable items not sparkling certainly will. I was able to solve this issue by restarting the game, but it's still annoying and meant lost progress.

All in all though, I would still recommend Contrast.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Though visually stunning and in employ of a very interesting game mechanic I'd never seen before-- the manipulation of lights in order to traverse through a shadow-world to allow the player access to areas that are otherwise unreachable,-- I felt that these two points were not enough to make up for the amount of glitches and the weak plot that I found in an otherwise palatable game. For the amount I bought it for, I felt this game was not polished very well, and it certainly doesn't help that the secondary character you follow was written in a very annoying manner. Noir games are often hit-or-miss because of the amount of stereotypes the genre builds upon, and Contrast followed the routine noir atmosphere and plotline.\n\nIn short, this was a very imaginative game, but I don't see myself going back to it for another playthrough. I would recommend it for the shadow/light manipulation, however.

reviewText: Contrast was refreshingly different in the way it allowed players to manipulate both two and three dimensional worlds. Set in a noir atmosphere of Paris you play as Dawn, the imaginary friend of Didi Malenkaya. Dawn is able to jump in between shadows, sometimes by altering with light sources to assist Didi on her journey to reunite her broken family. I enjoyed finding collectables throughout the levels which gave background and a deeper connection to the characters. Would definately recommend Contrast to those who want to try something new.

reviewText:
This game is beautiful with a great soundtrack that fits the game wonderfully. The unique ability to switch between the 3D real world and the 2D shadow world to solve puzzles and complete tasks is what really drew my attention. The execution was fantastic and better than my expectations.

My only complaint is how short this game was. The ending was a little sudden, and I was left wanting more, at least one more act. I really hope there is a contrast 2 that finishes the story or at least continues it. I think I was offline for maybe half of the game, so the 2.7 hours is not accurate, probably closer to 5-6 hours.

I would definitely recommend this game.

reviewText: Great game!  This game is a story-rich, highly stylized, puzzle platformer.  It's main mechanic is changing from 3D platforming and shadow shifting into 2D platforming (as well as using the shadows to move things like boxes and balls that you also shift into the 2D shadow world).  It tells the story of a little girl and her doting father and mother (as well as a quirky magician) as the doting father tries to win his way back into his mother's graces (with you and the daughter's help).\n\nI really enjoyed the mechanics.  Although they are spotty and inconsistent sometimes (but they did this all with the Unreal Engine, which is amazing work in my opinion), but the vast majority of the time they work perfectly fine.  The music is great too!  If you like video games as art
date: this is definitely one of them.

reviewText: I'm a bit perplexed by Contrast. On the one hand, this game has beautiful art direction, amazing design for it's levels and world, an enjoyable and somewhat intricate story and characters, and a fantastic gameplay mechanic. Now all of these good points are really good, don't get me wrong. The problem is that the game could do so much more with them, and inevitably you are left with a pool of really good if not great ideas that never really amount to much.\nThe game is definatly good, and I hope that Compulsion will revisit it in the future to flesh out these ideas. I have no problem recomending this game, perhaps buy it while on a sale as it is very short, but I feel like it might still be worth the full price simply to experience these great ideas. And if there is a Contrast 2, I will be there to buy it on day one.

reviewText: I saw this game at PAXEast last year.  The demo made it clear that I'd want to see this when it came out.  Then I lost track and never heard about it until I saw it on sale here.  I grabbed it and played it.  Very fun game, novel concept and very well executed.  The platforming is fun with the shadow mechanic. The ambiance and story are VERY well made.  The game is short but very well executed.  It's worth the small money they are asking for.\n\nI wish more game developers put as much into the style and aesthetic that these guys did!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Charming little game, with shadow semantics that bring a breath of fresh air to the platform genre. It twists your way of thinking and never quite leaves you sure which world is the real one, 3D or the 2D one. Play this for the story which gives off just enough details to be intruiging but also to leave you guessing and filling in the gaps.

Game itself works mostly well, there were a few times when the shadow hoping was a bit glitchy (would drop me out and I had to retry a few times) but overall worked well. The puzzles are engaging and imaginative. The only downside is that the game is short with only 3 chapters which I finished in just over 3h.

Still worth playing through. 7.5/10

reviewText:
Rated: 6/10

The controls aren't terrible, but the games collision detection bugs out once in a while. I also ran into a puzzle that I had to restart manually because I had bugged it by accident. One time I ascended a tower by walking upwards on air... these are the bugs/collisions I'm talking about.

That being said if the art style captivates you I would suggest playing the game. The games puzzles aren't to complicated, but the unique shadow mechanic is a nice deviation from other titles. The story and music perfectly match the art. So this game won't be a thumbs up by everybody, but I enjoyed myself.

reviewText:
Well rounded story line. I like how it doesn't even tell you who you are or why you exist when you first start.

I would recomend this to someone who enjoys puzzles, mysteries and to-the-point games.

It's pretty much open map, you can go anywhere at any time, you can be in the middle of a challange and just walk back out the front door (if you can make it back there) and go somewhere else, though unless you're searchig for more luminaries, there's not much point. There are a couple of things you can collect on the side: luminares and collectables. The collectables are like a little side story/mission, but like I said, the game is pretty much to the point and doesn't waste much time.
I feel like I just read a really interesting novela.

reviewText: The gameplay itself is a bit buggy, but it's worth buying on sale. Beautiful atmosphere, cute story, great voice acting and music. It's a generally clever game that uses the play itself as a metaphor.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Amazing game! Not only do you get to explore a nice French 1932 environment with some interesting achievements, you get to run along walls and use the light and shadows to your advantage. Can't reach that high up balcony? Shift the light around until shadows form for you to walk on. Simple, short, but so much fun!

Does this game have downsides? Yes, it does, but nothing much to make you stop playing. For one, this game is fairly short, only three acts. I played 8 hours and got all the collectibles and achievements. And I'm not even too great at platformers. Also, as demonstrated in the trailer, the little girl you with helps you along the shadows by holding up a stick. Sadly (SPOILER), that is the only time that happens. I think they could've used that mechanic better.

Still, I'd say this game is a definate must-buy, if you can get it on a discount. 8/10, mostly because of flawless gameplay, beautiful art-design and great jazzy music.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Gorgeous game! I loved the soundtrack, the aesthetics, and the whole concept! Each puzzle is very unique and some are pretty difficult, so the game never got repretitive and stayed interesting. Admittedly, the controls are a little clunky during some puzzles, but it isn't so bad that any puzzle is impossible to complete. You may just have to die or fall a few times before you can get it just right. The game only runs about 4 or 5 hours from start to finish, plus a little more if you have to replay a few chapters to complete all of the achievements. For the relatively short game length, the story is actually very well developed; however, the focus is obviously the puzzles and not story-rich content, so don't expect anything too in-depth.\n\nAll in all, I was very impressed!

reviewText:
Its a unique game, the shifting into the shadows gameplay is it's major selling point but it also has quite nice art, music and storyline.

As some of the other reviews hinted - everything in this game is really good but it's lacking some tiny bit of extra wowfactor which would really make it amazing.

I didn't find any terrible bugs.  But it does have issues, sort of like you would expect an infinite possibility sandbox environment to have issues.  It uses the dynamic shadows cast by the graphics engine as part of the gameplay, and sometimes that isn't going to work out right as there's just too many possible shadows that can be created.  I imagine it's damn near impossible to test properly as shadows can be different in a thousand ways.

The shadow play can be a bit annoying as you fall out of the shadows and back into the 3D world a little too easily.  And once (spoiler!) I shifted an item with me into the shadows and managed to lose it completely somewhere.. take care of your precious metal balls! :)

But anyway, the game is short and sweet, play it if you like unusual games.

reviewText: Ok I will make this quick and concise. This is a beautiful game, with great writing, solid ideal mechanics and a fun asthetic. But the coding is so bad. This game is not a puzzle game, often times you will figure out the puzzle then retry it 10-30 times because it's actually a near pixle perfect platformer, has completely unreliable physics which is what makes it maddening. I want to get involved with this story I dont want to try a jump 20 times in a row where it takes 10 times to figure out exactly when I have to jump to not drop out of shadow then another 10 to figure out what rotating object I have to get on that will get to the top. So if you are a patient person who loves old school platfpormers, you will like this game, if you are a story based person who likes solving puzzles this game will drive you crazy.

reviewText:
Here are the cliffnotes of a review I wrote for this game elswhere:
I’ve had this game on my Steam wishlist for a few months now and decided to grab it during the Winter Sale last week. I’m glad I did because, in retrospect, I wouldn’t have wanted to waste more money than I already did on it.
This is not something that I would call a puzzle game. A puzzle implies that there is an intricate mental test to perform that has a rewarding outcome if you can find and place all the pieces. To solve the puzzles in this game you just have to perform trial and error because there really is no intuitive puzzle to be had. You platform around as a shadow on the wall to perform an arbitrary task and that’s about it. The “puzzle” aspect comes in, I GUESS, when you turn a wheel or press a button and the shadows move and you continue platforming. Maybe it’s that some of the buttons are on timers? I suppose some people would consider that a puzzle……But if you find those people, please, remind them to take the plastic bag off of their head once in awhile.
Bottom line: I wouldn’t recommend this game unless you have a big hard-on for platformers….But there ARE better platformers…..Much better.
I’ve played about an hour and a half of the game and I’m over half done. I just simply don’t see any point in prolonging the review. I’m probably not even going to get around to finishing this game.

reviewText: I would recommend this game with only really one word of caution.  On the plus side it is one of the most atmospheric games that I have played in a long time.  It both looks and sounds fantastic and really evokes 1920s Paris and has an interesting central concept which gives excellent gameplay.  It always good to see developers trying something different and I found this to be highly original and was one of the reasons I originally bought the game.\n\nFor me the game very engrossing for the time I was playing it, however be aware this is a short game.  I wrapped it up in just over 3 hours, and whilst I think the atmosphere of the game is sufficient to generate a repeat playing at some point in the future it is a puzzle solving game so this may limit that.

reviewText: Although it only took me a few hours to play through, I thoroughly enjoyed this game. The characters are memberable, the environment incredibly detailed in a steampunk Alice in Wonderland style, and the music is superb. The main mechanic of the game - switching between physical 3D space and shadows 2D space is well done and an interesting mechanic to spend the game time fully wrapping your head around. Controller support is well mapped, if you prefer it.\n\nSave for a single annoying puzzle, I definitely recommend this for any platformer or story-based game fan.

reviewText: I'm a sucker for engrossing environments, and poking around through Contrast's surroundings feels like perusing a Dali exhibit at times. While you're enjoying the ambience, there's a story about a little girl with family troubles that likes to sneak around at night. You play as her mute shadow-friend, swapping between 3Dspace and the 2D shadows cast upon the world.\n\nThe puzzles are fairly straightforward, although some will take a bit of experimentation. Solving them is less about flipping switches and more comparable to turning the hands on a clock to the correct time: it's difficult to get them in the precise orientation for success, but more often than not you'll get close enough." As a result of this
date: a good number of the puzzles left me feeling like I'd somehow found an alternate
recommended: unintended solution from point A to B. This was actually the case once or twice
hoursPlayed: as I had found a way to sneak past a goal and into the next room with no way to continue since I didn't take the expected route. Reloading a previous save and checking online for the actual solution was my workaround that one time. I've uploaded a screenshot of this area so you don't get stuck like I did.\n\nThe shadow-swappy controls are fun
voteText: and the game doesn't overstay its welcome

reviewText: As someone who went into this game with little expectation - due to ignorance not due to any negative view point - I can say that I'm incredibly impressed.  The shadow mechanic that is the main aspect of this game is incredibly well done and the puzzles and platforming are challenging without feeling as though they are impossible.  The plot was thick and gripping enough to keep me interested in the characters I interacted with, but not so overwhelming that it felt like the puzzles were filling in the space between cut scenes.\n\nI would absolutely recommend playing this game if you're intersted in puzzle or platforming games.  I would also recommend it if you enjoy playing games that are plot-heavy.

reviewText:
Disliked: Some of the mechanics were a little rough. Also, could've been a little longer, but good pacing for what it was; a short film noir puzzle.

Liked: Everything else. I'm a story-rich fan, and this did not disappoint. Interesting story, if not a little predictable. Surreal environment. GREAT music! Loved the twist on the 2D/3D game play. Beautiful graphics and animations, beyond what the game really does. They spent a lot of time making it look nice and not enough time to let you really soak up the neighborhood.

Overall, well worth the Christmas sale price, but might not buy it at full because it was over too soon.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Contrast is a unique game where you play as a young girl's imaginary friend, and the only visible characters are yourself and the girl. Other characters will show up throughout and you can jump all over their shadows they cast on walls, and the game's mechanics and puzzles involve you weaving through shadow and 3D to reach your destination.

This game is short and sweet. Can really be played through in one sitting without a problem (especially if you don't go on a hunt for the random collectibles which some made no sense and said things as nondescript as 'science photo'- I had to find them because completionist)

Some of the movement within the shadows can be finicky at times, but isn't much of an issue since there aren't really load screens or repercussions for dying. Just a fun puzzler that follows the active imagination of a young girl and her love for her family.

reviewText:
So... Contrast.

The short version is this: great soundtrack, decent game, decent story, way too short and the ending is a bit rushed and predictable.

The longer version is this: I personally really enjoyed the game.  The style of the game was really well done.  Some of the mechanics were interesting, such as using the shadows of people in conversation to reach a new location.  That said, the ending really did feel a bit rushed, and, assuming you find a few of the (extremely easy to find) collectibles, extremely easy to predict.  Would I recommend it?  For $15, definitely; I think I paid $20 for the pre-order + soundtrack, which I'm still okay with, considering I'm a sucker for this style of music and atmosphere.

Anyway, if you've got $15 to spare, support some indie devs and give it a shot.
