reviewText:
Pros:
- Great platforming controls, both 2d and 3d.
- Beautiful artstyle and graphics.
- Interesting collectibles
- Very fun to play.

Cons:
- It only took me 3 hours to beat the game, and I was only missing one collectible. (I hope theres some dlc plans)
- The story can be lackluster overall, though it has it's moments.
- Ran into a glitch at the carousel where I already activated the controls then left the area, and when I came back, it prompted me to put the luminaries into the controls, while it was already full. I couldn't turn back on the carousel, and was forced to restart the level.

Overall, a really good game! I wouldn't say it's worth 14.99,  as it's only 3 hours long, but it'll be a good short experience!

reviewText: Great game!  This game is a story-rich, highly stylized, puzzle platformer.  It's main mechanic is changing from 3D platforming and shadow shifting into 2D platforming (as well as using the shadows to move things like boxes and balls that you also shift into the 2D shadow world).  It tells the story of a little girl and her doting father and mother (as well as a quirky magician) as the doting father tries to win his way back into his mother's graces (with you and the daughter's help).\n\nI really enjoyed the mechanics.  Although they are spotty and inconsistent sometimes (but they did this all with the Unreal Engine, which is amazing work in my opinion), but the vast majority of the time they work perfectly fine.  The music is great too!  If you like video games as art
date: this is definitely one of them.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Now here's a unusual game.

I'm all about the story. For me a game can get away with average gameplay and a great story, but this game does well in both aspects, great story and great gameplay. Add to that the great artwork, a noir atmosphere, some sad jazz tunes, and you have a game worth keeping.
I'm still about halfway through (I suppose). But I've been hooked onto this game. You get to play a silent protagonist who can shift from the real world and into shadows. Shifting into a shadow makes you able to use shadows as a 2D platforms to traverse otherwise impossible to cross areas. You can use shadows as bridges or a sort of transportation device. In the real world (or should I say 3D), you get around just like any 3D platforming game. While in 3D mode you can move objects or light sources to arrange shadows in a way that could help you through some obstacles. The combination of 3D and 2D platforming make for interesting puzzles and a unique gameplay.
Definitely, a game worth buying, sale or no sale.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Contrast is nothing short of a work of art. The atmosphere immerces you right away as the art style, astounding music and the overall world feeling come together in fleshing out the film noir setting. The game mechanic is also very interesting, sure to satisfy both those who look for a puzzle and those who enjoy platforming, and if you like exploring and collectables you're gonna find plenty of that as well. Special mention to the sound track that might be worth the game price by itself if you're into that kind of music.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A stunning game. Brilliant concept backed up by some really nice graphics. The storyline is so engaging that I found it hard to put down. The puzzles were often a touch of genius. Not that they were difficult, only one or two stumped me and even then only for a short while. The genius is in the way they suck you into the story a little more each time. Especially the 'flashback' puzzles which can be tricky but never frustrating because the scene you are replaying is always a poignant moment in the story.
The soundtrack sets the tone just right and the voice acting is spot on. In particular Teale Bishopric was amazingly good as Didi.
Yes I have a few gripes. Jumping could be frustrating at times because it's a little to sensitive to collisions and it would have been nice to be able to customize the key mapping but that's about it.
It's a short game but one I will remember for a long time. I think it's almost the perfect length for the story. Yes I would have liked more but that's because I enjoyed it so much.

reviewText:
Rated: 6/10

The controls aren't terrible, but the games collision detection bugs out once in a while. I also ran into a puzzle that I had to restart manually because I had bugged it by accident. One time I ascended a tower by walking upwards on air... these are the bugs/collisions I'm talking about.

That being said if the art style captivates you I would suggest playing the game. The games puzzles aren't to complicated, but the unique shadow mechanic is a nice deviation from other titles. The story and music perfectly match the art. So this game won't be a thumbs up by everybody, but I enjoyed myself.

reviewText:
Well rounded story line. I like how it doesn't even tell you who you are or why you exist when you first start.

I would recomend this to someone who enjoys puzzles, mysteries and to-the-point games.

It's pretty much open map, you can go anywhere at any time, you can be in the middle of a challange and just walk back out the front door (if you can make it back there) and go somewhere else, though unless you're searchig for more luminaries, there's not much point. There are a couple of things you can collect on the side: luminares and collectables. The collectables are like a little side story/mission, but like I said, the game is pretty much to the point and doesn't waste much time.
I feel like I just read a really interesting novela.

reviewText: Contrast is a platformer/puzzle game with good graphics and a fair story. I can honestly say if it is patched and expanded on it could lead to something really great. As a stand alone game it shows heart in design and creativity. It is not without its faults it that collision could be a little finicky and the story is not tremendously detailed but i guess you can say that is the charm of the game. Its a simple game with plenty of heart and a small price tag so that anyone can afford it. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Contrast is a nice little puzzler/platformer with some really pleasant touches. The basic concept of using shadows is just really inventive, and being able to manipulate them meant that the level design became even more impressive. I loved the concept. I thought the world imagery was great with soemwhere between a 1930's dreamscape, and the music were wonderfully sultry and bluesy. The visuals are of a good standard too with a clear style. Overall its a very clever game, with some really well thought through touches and a great feel to it\nOn the bad side, the puzzles are a little easy to complete and the game is just too short. I don't consider myself to be a particularly good platform player, so with only 5 hours to complete the whole thing, it felt a bit lacking in depth. The plot was good enough, though I felt there was more of a story to tell, so it could've done with more development. The controls are a little glitchy at times too and you'll miss jumps. Overally not a bad game at all but needed more to it. Will give it a comfortable 8 / 10\n

reviewText: A very charming puzzle-platformer with a very impressive motif and soundtrack. The story of the game largely revolves around a broken family trying to piece itself together and is at its best when it focuses on their trials and tribulations. (It takes a weird turn near the end trying to answer questions I never asked about the broken shadow dimension that protagonist Dawn inhabits that just end up raising even more questions, but that treads into spoiler territory.) Manipulating shadows so that Dawn can become a shadow and platform across them proved to be an interesting challenge that had me scratching my head more than a few times, and they were never afraid of introducing new elements (even if some of those elements involved box-switch puzzles seen in many games before). The game is definitely a bit on the short side, however, and the only thing that kept me from clearing it 100% on my first run was a few collectibles and one item that was only available for a short time frame and ended up being lost forever. It's also very story-focused, and relies heavily on cutscenes to tell its tale. Overall, it's definitely flawed (probably rushed a bit to be a PS4 launch title), but it's an enjoyable game that should be tried.

reviewText: Coming away from Contrast after some thought – it’s come to me that this is a game that I enjoyed more for its theme. I stuck with the game for its amazing setting, lovely soundtrack and to see the end of the story, rather than staying for its 3D-to-2D shifting gameplay. The shortness of the game means that the puzzle mechanics are never given the time to fully grow. Mix this up with some questionable glitches and you’re left with a game that isn’t as well constructed as one would like.\n\nContrast is a curious, fair attempt at a puzzle platformer with some neat ideas that make it somewhat enjoyable, but is a slightly frustrating experience that in the end won’t be remembered for its gameplay, but more for its world, visuals and sound.

reviewText:
A neat little indie with a cool gameplay hook, but Contrast falls short of its potential.  Contrast has a patchwerk story, which is incredibly unfortunate given the potential of the lore (it's visibly rushed despite a very interesting world).  I love the art style, and particularly love the 2D/3D platforming crossovers.  Contrast cleverly utilises intricate 3D world objects to affect the 2D world (to use a basic example that doesn't spoil the puzzles, dragging an item closer to the light to make the shadow on the wall bigger).  It has a 'cute' companion character and touches on some of the deeper issues surrounding families, but it only lasts about 2-3 hours on a slow playthrough.  I would say about 20-30 minutes of that focuses on the story, and the majority is spent trying to figure out the tricks for the puzzles.  Once you work them out, you could probably play from start to finish in less than an hour, without skipping.

There are two types of collectibles.  One type of collectible comes from exploring and overcoming optional puzzles, and is essentially useless outside of the few occasions you need them to progress (When you need them to progress, they're very easy to find).  The other works to build up the lore, and it's quite expansive.  These collectibles flesh out the story in much greater detail than the main storyline, but mostly they serve to highlight just how unfortunate it is that Contrast was cut short.

The pros:
An old-fashioned setting with a great accompanying visual style
Cool dynamics between 2D and 3D elements
Some deep themes around family
Clever use of mechanics in puzzles
Interesting lore

The cons:
Shallow and disjointed story, with a very rushed ending.
The majority of playtime and difficulty comes from initially working out puzzle styles
An irrelevant collection system (not referring to the lore collectibles)

The verdict:
Pick it up if you enjoy games with a sense of uniqueness, or the potential for depth (rather than depth itself).  Contrast will test your lateral thinking (though only on a few occasions), and it touches on some pretty cool concepts.

Contrast is a game that grows on you and leaves you wanting more.

reviewText:
I'm going to recommend this game, but I will give a caveat - I bought it on a good sale, when it was under 4 bucks.  At that price, it's well worth it.  At full price... probably not.

This is a nice little game, with a really fantastic concept - the idea of shifting in and out of a 2D shadow world, and solving puzzles by moving objects and lights in 3D in order to properly align their shadows in 2D is very clever.  The music and atmosphere is quite nice as well, and the voice acting is well-done.  The story is a little thin, but I can't complain too much about that.

Now, the down sides.  First off, the game is quite short.  I completed it in just a few hours, and I'm sure many players could do it in even less time.  Also, the controls are a little... I don't know how to describe it, exactly.  Often, when working in the 3D world, the camera will drift a little oddly, and you end up running into a wall unintentionally.  In the 2D world, you find yourself occasionally falling out of the shadows for small things - bumping into the wrong shadow, jumping across a wall of a darker color.  Not consistently, and not enough to ruin the game, but enough to make it a little frustrating occasionally.  Control just doesn't always feel right.

While there are some good puzzles, and the atmosphere is quite interesting, often it feels like the designers weren't quite sure what to do with the concept.  Finally, gameplay is interrupted far too often by cutscenes.  I understand the desire to tell the story, and to set the stage for each new area, but it is annoying when control is taken from you every 5 minutes or so.

This review ended up seeming a lot more negative than I actually feel about the game.  As I said at the start, if you get it on sale for less that 5 dollars or so, I think it's worth it, if you enjoy casual puzzle games with a unique atmosphere.  Ultimately, though, I would love to see this concept fleshed out more in another game.  It's a great idea that this game just couldn't quite do justice to.

reviewText:
Contrast is game that I liked, but I can easily see why some people might dislike it, and why it got so low score on Metacritic.

1) Gameplay

Contrast comes up with a great concept, but it's been poorly made. The idea of changing from 2D to 3D really inovates (even though there was already a game that came with a concept a lot like that called Perspective, it's a f2p game, go and check it yourself), and brings lots of great moments, but also buggy ones. There were moments where the puzzle wasn't the challenge it self, but the glitches.
There were also mechanics that could have been more exploited.

2) Art/ Soundtrack/ Voiceacting

The atmosphere of the game is well built by the scenario and the sound track, art desgin really fit's in, but there are problems. The animations weren't much organic (and seem really half baked), there were buggy shadows and some halfbaked props, missing collison on places where it clearly should have something.
The voice acting actually impressed me. It's not exceptional, but it fits in to the characters really nicely.

3) Story

The story of Contrast may be for some one of the strogesnt points, but I have to disagree a little bit on that one.
The story really intrigued me, and it really got me thinking, but there were some really strange moments.
Sometimes it's to obvious that the developers didn't have in mind much about the story, only about the gamplay. But it's a nice story, and the gap for theories are wide open for interpretetions. There are some people making some deep theories, but to  be honest, I don't think they really thought about all that.

4)Conclusion:
It's a nice expirience, but it seems like the game was rushed, it's short and there are lots of things that could have been more polished. It's worth a try

Extremely short, but very good game.  Unless you are a collector and want to find everthing in this game you can beat it in about 2 hours.  If you like collecting and learning a bit more about this lore of the game it take about 3.5 hours depending how good you are at solving these puzzles.
Over all  The controlls where excellent, a little sticky here and there in certain spot probably from my own doing.
There are a few spots in the game though if you lose a critical piece to the puzzle you must killl yourself to restart that part to get that critical piece back.  It was kind of annoying to have to jump off a ledge to respawn a box that I needed to have for a very small part of a leve.
Overall the visuall are fantastic, the use of light and shadows are amazing and it takes into effect 2D planes.
Over all if you want to kill a few hours with a very good puzzle game I would download this, But due to the shortness of the game I would suggest to buy it on a sale or give it to a friend when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
A living embodiment of 3d puzzle combined with the 2D style platformer such that of Limbo. The atmosphere of the game set around the 1920's with its Jazzy influences and the developments of magic shows really opened up a spectacular mystery genre to the art of the game. For a few moments, the game looked easy and only required persistence to get through levels, but eventually requiring more brainwork than eye hand coordination as the levels progressed in acts II and III. What seemed like a memory of the protagonist, Didi, becomes a reality in this magical game of shadows and their players.

Overall, one of those masterpieces of 2013 if only the game wasn't so heavy on a simple graphics card!
9/10

reviewText: Contrast, to put into a single word, is marvelous. Its graphics are well detailed, and the way that light is used in this game is borderline genius. The voicework is well done for all characters. The music is excellent, being very rythmic and jazzy. And the story is quite interesting. The collection of collectable that you can obtain is both expansive and impactful for the length of the game. The Bioshock-esque way of using collectables to explain plot points was well done. It was always interesting to read an article about a missing person, or seeing a picture of the scientific" explainations of the shadow world. The light puzzles that are used are especially interesting because the game mechanic of switching between two worlds is wonderfully unique and fun. All of these factors really combine to create an incredible atmosphere.\nHowever no game is without its imperfections. Though I do
recommended: recommend this game to anyone who wants a interesting experience

column17: true
column19: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Concept
A 2D/3D platformer where you can merge with walls to become a shadow. Utilize this to explore new possibilities in platforming.

Story
The game is divided up into chapters and acts, which you can select from the main screen if you wish. However, the game is really short. I clocked in with about 4 hours on my first playthrough, an hour of which I don't think I was playing. In addition, some mechanic frustrations also prolonged my playthrough.

You play as a character named Dawn, whom only Didi can see. Didi is a child of a broken family who is trying to get back together leading to the different levels you encounter. Sometimes this leads to some interesting levels.

The game also tries to induce a little mystery of if Dawn is real or not and what exactly is she. However, the game doesn't go too far along that route that it doesn't really matter, especially at the end.

Graphics
The graphics are okay. I had to run this on low settings so I cannot testify how great it can be besides online videos and pictures. I also wonder if the lack of some environment is a result of my computer or design. It does lead to some cool views. The shadow style is a pretty nifty idea that helps distract the player. As I was watching the cutscenes, I was wondering if people can be charmed by simply a shadow on the wall and a voice.

Sound
The game has a Jazz music style. It fits with the setting, and the vocals aren't bad in that respect.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kjMxRkKnnOI#t=27

The vocals are actually fairly good too. Didi can get annoying sometimes, but sometimes her actions actually brought a smile. It's interesting that Dawn is voiceless but I guess that's to keep the player guessing what she is exactly and if she's real.

Gameplay
This game had a lot of promise. The idea of manipulating shadows to create solid platforming makes it a small thinking game as well. When I was little, I used to contemplate how interesting it would be if you can become a shadow. This game allows me to play with that idea a little bit, but not as much as I would have liked.

You are given 5 basic controls for most of the game. Movement, Interaction, Shifting, Jump, and Dash. You also have control of the camera, which leads me to controller preferences. You do not want to play this game with a mouse and keyboard if you can avoid it. The camera is controlled with the mouse, which you also use for Dash and Shifting. This becomes a problem when you accidently move the camera while meaning to shift or dash. It has led me to many frustrations. The camera setting with the mouse is also too sensitive even after I adjusted it to get it right. When I switched to a 360 controller, the experience improved greatly. The camera was fine and my hands were less confused with which button was shift and which was dash.

This game has no action in it, which is good for this style. Since there are no enemies to fight, you can focus on the platforming and puzzles you are given. The promise of the game expands with the different mechanics you find in the different chapters. There is some room for exploration, but not too much freedom. ONe time when I wanted to wander, Didi would interfere and force me to continue.

Speaking of Didi, this game started to make me think about useless companions in video games; Didi is one of them. While you need to follow her to know what you next mission is, she never really helps you out. There is one occasion where she helps you out in the story and that is it. It's a shame because the image I posted near the top seemed to promise that you can use Didi to create an environment for you. There is one particular scene where I wish I could have controlled Didi to use something she was right next to instead of me doing something more complex than it needed.

One of the things that could use some fine tuning is the mechanics. I resorted to Gamefaqs for one thing only to find that I was doing it right all along, but the game mechanics would screw it up.  The glitch I'm referring to is the game forcing you or an object to shift out where it shouldn't. Eventually I got it to work, but I was still upset over the whole thing. Unfortunately, the mechanics would still be glitchy every now and then, forcing me to restart multiple times when I should have easily progressed. It's a shame too, because if it wasn't for the occasional glitchy mechanics, it would have been a solid platformer. The game does have some redemption on the matter by giving you multiple checkpoints to restart from when you die and it doesn't take too long to reload.

Replayability
As mentioned before, the game is short and you can select specific chapters to play again. However, with the frustrations I encountered with the mechanics, and the story not being so grand, I probably would stay away from it for a while before trying to play again.

Overall
This is one of those little disappointments for me. The game has promise and it shows it in sparks throughout the game. Unfortunately, it never completely capitalizes on it's potential. It can give you an interesting experience, but I think I would have more faith if they did a sequel with solid mechanics. This is a game where you might want to wait for a good sale before you buy it (maybe $5-7).

My recommendation is for platforming fans who want to try something a little different. If you play with a controller and on a computer that can run it smoothly, then it is less frustrating and possible to enjoy.


Taken from my blog at http://www.ign.com/blogs/falconrise/2014/02/16/game-review-contrast-for-pc

reviewText:
Contrast is one of those games that has a good premise - the idea of use light and shadows to create a separate bit of 2D puzzle gameplay from the normal 3D world, but the implementation from a story and setting as well as design is a bit disconnected.  The technical approach is good in how you can shift in an our of shadows, but the problem is that the areas you can do this in are very limited and separated from each other, making each puzzle its own microcosm.   The puzzles that use this aren't that difficult as well, with the most difficult ones being where you can either move objects to change shadows or the location of the light source. Again, with the puzzles being separate entities, these are one-stop problems as opposed to part of a larger difficult mechanism to figure out.

The story is interesting but it's hard to get into and leaves some questions on getting into the characters. Whether this is a fantasy, a dream, or something else isn't clear, and whether it is a flashback or the like.  As such, the game quickly devolves into just moving from puzzle to puzzle with story getting in the way.

It is still a decent game, but it's one I'd wait for a sale for, getting about 3 hrs of playtime from it.

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best puzzle games I've played. If you have any liking for French jazz culture, this is the game for you. It is all about using light in creative ways to solve puzzles, most of which are platforming.

My favorite pieces are the music which was put together with care. The vocalist they hired to sing a couple songs has the perfect voice for this type of jazz. All of the voice acting is quite solid. The other piece that drew me in was the use of shadows to represent characters rather than physical beings. I think that is explained through collectibles, but I haven't spent much time with it. Contrast also manages to portray a sense of innocence surrounding Didi while giving some very adult conflicts when she's not around.

The only real issue I had was with either the controls or the design, I'm not sure. Sometimes when something seemed easy to accomplish, like a jump, you'd be force off the wall for some reason and have to start over. Basically I think some of the shadows in the environment were unintentional and created surprise blocks for you to avoid. It could also just be I'm not very practiced at platformers. The puzzles seem well designed and not too challenging to figure out. After figuring out what needs to be done, you may still need to take a few tries at it before succeeding, but it isn't usually too frustrating.

It is quite a short game if you figure out the puzzles quickly, it took me maybe 6 hours. So I probably wouldn't buy it for full price just because of the length, but I would definitely buy it on sale. Also, the soundtrack is a great jazz compilation.

One last note: at I believe the end of the first act, there are two endings depending on if you just stand and watch, or actively do something (I don't want to give spoilers) If you don't do anything, you'll fail the level and be put back to the beginning of the dialogue, so I recommend just listening first, then actually doing what you're supposed to.

reviewText:
‘Constrast’ is a game of the platformer variety, centred around a puzzle mechanic which uses light and shadows as a mean of switching between a 3D and 2D environment, but it becomes completely irredeemable by committing the capital sin for platformers : bad controls. The game simply doesn’t work at what it is trying to do and, as such, is utterly unrecommendable.

It starts… bad, and only gets worse. The game has no rebindable keys, the mouse cursor doesn’t work in every menu (like restarting a checkpoint or leaving the game), but it does offer very lacklustre graphic options. Although I like the style of the game, I really disliked its graphics quality. The textures aren’t pretty, and there is nothing to distract from them, as the environments are lifeless and empty. Even the music doesn’t help, as it is barely even present while you are exploring or solving puzzles. Worse, one of the main mechanics of the game requires you to play with shadows, but even they are barebones at best. In the days of soft focus shadows, that’s a big no-no if your main mechanic revolves around them. All the cutscenes and story bits are shown through the shadows too, so you get to experience bad graphics on top of very stick figure-like animations, not even remotely human. Not that it really matters as the story holds no water, but I will get to that in a minute.
But alright, let’s give it the benefit of the doubt, what else is there? Any other nitpicks? Well, even though I’m a native French speaker, I preferred the English dub, but the collectibles, with press articles and other, supposedly, world building information extracts, aren’t fully translated! That’s disappointing.

What about the gameplay? Well, the controls aren’t rebindable, the camera is atrocious, -which doesn’t help-, and the animation of the character is stiff and “mechanic”. Clunky really, fast and yet without precision. When the camera switches mode, between locked in 2D shadow world and free 3D exploration, it is feels horrible: during the transitions, it is either too quick or too slow, but feels unnatural either way, jarring. You don’t feel in control, you are at the mercy of the game’s whims.
So let me get this straight. It is a puzzle platformer with bad controls and bad camera, where you have to jump on platforms made from poorly rendered shadows, from which you will end up sliding off for the smallest offense. This will lead to some frustration since… well, you character doesn’t move like you want it to or the game just refuses to acknowledge your input, for whatever reason, and getting sacked for it, unfairly, is rather infuriating. It is actually so bad, I landed in a secret area one time, one I hadn’t neither seen nor planned on jumping into. Thanks for that I guess, but it isn’t gonna make up for all the bad jump related deaths.

As said before, even the story didn’t hold my attention. In all honesty, I had a hard time sympathizing with the dad figure. Because he was trying, although he put his family in harm’s way, that makes every alright? When you stand in the rain, you get wet. Don’t. Stand. In. The. Rain. Or least, don’t ask for my sympathy when you complain about getting drenched. The story didn’t resonate with me.

The nail in the coffin was one particular moment that is reminiscent of Limbo. Except, you know, Limbo kind of works. So now I have a better game in my mind that I could be playing on top of all this nonsense. Anyway, it was too obvious, with the spider and all… You haven’t earned that game, the right to make an ‘homage’ like that. And even if you did, you have a game that is three hours short (and thank god for that! I wouldn’t have been able to play any more of it), and you basically have so little to put in it that you lift levels from another game. That doesn’t come across as very endearing to me.

There is definitely an interesting concept at the core of the game, with the change between 3D and 2D platformer, and that’s where the puzzles are I suppose, if you can call them that. It is a proof of concept, sure, but that’s not enough for a good game. And it is actually possible to break the puzzles, making them impossible to solve, forcing you to reload if you aren’t careful enough, which you can’t be because of the horrendous controls! At times, it does feel like an endless cycle of displeasure. Certainly, that concept deserved better. As it stands, the game is a demo I would present to my boss in order to get funding for a project based around the shown concept, not a final product I would charge money for.

All in all, what I am seeing here is a game that had a great gameplay concept, and a great art style, but failed to get to the finish line with them. The game feels rushed, empty in a lot of aspect, barely functional sometimes, without any form of polish whatsoever, and it makes it all the more disappointing when the game does finally decide to work, when, very rarely, there are some “sparks” and it clicks. From time to time, things work out alright, and the puzzles and their solutions aren’t hampered by the flaws of the game, but those shining moments, where the transition from an open world to one of shadows stimulates your brain and gives you the satisfaction of actually solving a problem in a clever way, without the frustration of dealing with force outside your reach, are far too few to justify any consideration of purchase, no matter the price.

reviewText:
I had fun with Contrast, but I can't recommend this game on a good conscience. The game is short, puzzles easy and sometimes even tiresome, camera jittery and sticky, and I don't even remember the number of times that I got myself stuck behind some piece of furniture or even in the wall while using Dawn's dash ability because the game didn't plan for it. I'll give that perhaps I was having too much fun with that skill since walking is boring, so most might not run into that problem. Maybe. But since I had to restart multiple times just to continue the game (I even had to take a break at one point), it won't be a game that I'll be 100%ing. I want to, but I can't bring myself to despite it just being a couple more achievements.

Still, I enjoyed the music, especially the opening song, (I'll be keeping that OST, thank you very much.), the voice-acting for the adults (I really liked Johhny), and the alternative dialogue that the game has depending on what you do or don't do. On the other hand, as a character you play alongside for most of the game, Didi was simply too irritating for me; if the game devs were looking for the voice of an annoying child who thinks too highly of herself, they did excellently. The story is predictable if sweet, though I did like the unveiling of the past through collectibles.

Get it during a sale, if you must, but otherwise, I'd say the game is best enjoyed while someone else plays it; there is nothing in the game that I would say needs to be experienced first-hand. If anything, I'd say that the game makes a better show than a game. I had looked forward to some innovative or intricately done shadow mechanics, but it just ended up being disappointing and repetitive which is a shame.

Bottom line, I had fun. I enjoyed this game, and I will say that it deserves to be experienced, but not as the player of the game.

reviewText:
How and where to begin this review? Like most story driven games, I shall begin with the plot and the setting. Both of these strive very well indeed; however, due to the game's short length (roughly four hours for me), the story unravels greatly towards the end. You can see where Compulsion Games were wanting to go with it, but unforunately the developers were told to wrap it up, and it shows in Act III.

It was disappointing because the noir setting was surperb, and the story soars in Acts I and II. The music and voice acting are top notch. I also loved the idea of Dawn being an imaginary friend and the concept of traveling from the real world to the shadow world.

However, the controls in this game is what did it for me. The game is a platformer, which I admit that I am okay at them. Dawn would not stop getting stuck on little things or would pop out the shadow world even when there weren't any conflicting shadows nearby. There were also numerous times in which you should be able to jump onto a simple ledge in the 3D world that was only waist high; however, Dawn would refuse to jump onto it. And due to the game's short length the puzzles weren't that hard to solve. The mouse is what controls your camera angle, and it felt like you had to barely move it or else everything goes haywire.

All in all, Contrast is a game that had so much potential and soars through the air in the first two Acts. Then, it faceplants in the third act. I did buy this during the Steam Summer, so for just $7.99 (got the soundtrack as well) I did get my money's worth....just wished that there were tighter controls and a longer game length.

reviewText:
Nice little masterpiece.

If you like puzzle games (Portal, Limbo Braid-I wan't a fan), art, science, noir, old fashion and jazz music you will probably like this game.  Good atmosphere, nice unique story and gameplay, decent graphics and good controls. Good save points, so no need to repeat things many times if fall, which some short games do to make it seem longer-really that is just annoying. Short (4 hrs) and sweet so doesn't overstay its welcome with this unique niche and one you prob won't forget. You utilize shadows to move around and manipulate things.  If you can  get a sale for $10 or less its worth it imo.

9/10 for indie game standards.

reviewText: Very amazing and intriguing. At the time when I had bought it, I bought the collectors edition on sale for five dollars. I think that the price is good but the game is a bit short, probably in total of about six hours. I personally am not the best a games whatsoever, so while others may complain, it was a MAJOR help that the game held my hand all the way through. I absolutley love it, and would recomend it. It is a bit on the adult side rather than a childs game, but it's quite easy to understand. The only downside is how unique it is, because playing it again would be tiring. I say this because you can't just let the game blend in with others in your mind, if that makes any sense, making it difficult to forget your first experience with it.

reviewText:
A great, very short (4-5 hours) game filled with clever & nifty puzzles that make fascinating use of shadows and a sometimes sad but always (imho) captivating story that's fully fleshed out thanks to the many collectibles present within the game that tell the story within the story (be sure to collect them all to get the full picture to help you understand what's going on behind the scenes!).
Great voice acting & a fantastic song in the style of the cabaret or a lounge singer further complement the rest of the game to make this a great purchase worth every penny.

8.5/10

reviewText:
I've wanted to play this since I saw a trailer of it. The shadow mechanic is very cool and unique, but at the same time extremely frustrating. When you have control of light you have to fiddle with it for a while before you get it EXACTLY PERFECT for the puzzles to work. And I don't mean solvable. I mean at a point where the physics engine doesn't bug out and throw you out of the shadows for no good reason. It happens. A lot.

Pros:
Beautiful Art Style
Simple mechanics that show depth and complexity in how they are used.
A quite charming story, that isn't too overly long either.

Cons:
That stupid Physics engine thing. it will have you screaming and tearing your hair out.
Short-ish, I finished it in 3.5 hours.

The length I put as both a pro and a con, since some like shorter games and others like longer games.

Oh gosh. What can I even say about this game. Perect fits the bill. The art, the music, the voice acting, and the setting all fit together to create a delicious experience. This game is a feast of the senses. The story kept me searching for each new little clue into the lives of the characters. As a lover of story above all, this game delivered.

The gameplay is brilliant. The innovation that went into creating the puzzles kept astounding me as they got more and more involved. There were a few that had me jumping through shadows 180 degrees from what I needed to be doing. I'm not even mad, it was so much fun!

I love this game. I want to live in it. Can we make that happen? Pretty please?

reviewText: Contrast was refreshingly different in the way it allowed players to manipulate both two and three dimensional worlds. Set in a noir atmosphere of Paris you play as Dawn, the imaginary friend of Didi Malenkaya. Dawn is able to jump in between shadows, sometimes by altering with light sources to assist Didi on her journey to reunite her broken family. I enjoyed finding collectables throughout the levels which gave background and a deeper connection to the characters. Would definately recommend Contrast to those who want to try something new.

reviewText:
This game is beautiful with a great soundtrack that fits the game wonderfully. The unique ability to switch between the 3D real world and the 2D shadow world to solve puzzles and complete tasks is what really drew my attention. The execution was fantastic and better than my expectations.

My only complaint is how short this game was. The ending was a little sudden, and I was left wanting more, at least one more act. I really hope there is a contrast 2 that finishes the story or at least continues it. I think I was offline for maybe half of the game, so the 2.7 hours is not accurate, probably closer to 5-6 hours.

I would definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game was quite odd. As a game its nothing special; it would even be fair to say its gameplay is just bad. I often felt as though I tricked trough some levels by takng advantage of the hit-and-miss gameplay like making jumps that would avoid the puzzles. The stories execution is equally questionable, with a protagonist who serves to guide you through the game without any real finesse. And by that I don't mean your character; you seem to serve more as a tool for her tasks but that is the point.

TO THE GOOD!

This game had a very specific feel about it which I felt made it worth playing. The art style and music marry so well together that I forgave the shaky gameplay (at least for the most part). Depite its dodgy execution, I got what it was trying to show and it made for an enjoyable experience. The story wasn't as linear as what I've come to expect; whether thats a good or bad thing, im not entirely sure. Its fair to say Didi (the young girl) was a bit 'pushy' in trying to force you into the story, but I didnt really mind as my character is there to help her and the interactions of the character felt right for the situation.

Theres plenty to find out beyond the game through exploration. I actually think these bits were what made the game as it added another level of story beyond Didi's life to something more personal for the character Dawn (who never speaks IIRC), also - great name without being something cheesy. I would throughly recommend you endevour to find the 20(I think?) hidden media snippets! It reminded me of Bioshock in that the information you find explains the situation youre in; but in a modest way.

This game however is by no means difficult! I did the entire story in a single 2 hour sitting and found everything in that time. This wasn't even deliberately to finish it, I just felt like the game never lost traction and felt so, almost, calm to play that I kept casually playing. This isnt to say the story was good; it was weak with the hidden snippets making it interesting but it was solid enough in terms of character and situation.

Overall, as someone who does try to game as much as possible, I can't honestly say its a great game. But for me, it was incredibly playable and I will revisit it again gladly. It was like listening to music, I did indeed just easily loose track of time and do it. I found it quite charming if I'm being honest.

I played it with a controller if that means anything? You wont need the precision or focus of a kb+m but thats just my preference for this game. I would also say if youre on the fence about it, its probably best you wait till a sale comes around. I don't think I paid full price and despite enjoying it, don't know if its worth it. Definately feels like it should be £6.99 or similarly priced. Wouldn't be upset if I did pay retail though.

reviewText:
This is probably one of the best puzzle games I've played. If you have any liking for French jazz culture, this is the game for you. It is all about using light in creative ways to solve puzzles, most of which are platforming.

My favorite pieces are the music which was put together with care. The vocalist they hired to sing a couple songs has the perfect voice for this type of jazz. All of the voice acting is quite solid. The other piece that drew me in was the use of shadows to represent characters rather than physical beings. I think that is explained through collectibles, but I haven't spent much time with it. Contrast also manages to portray a sense of innocence surrounding Didi while giving some very adult conflicts when she's not around.

The only real issue I had was with either the controls or the design, I'm not sure. Sometimes when something seemed easy to accomplish, like a jump, you'd be force off the wall for some reason and have to start over. Basically I think some of the shadows in the environment were unintentional and created surprise blocks for you to avoid. It could also just be I'm not very practiced at platformers. The puzzles seem well designed and not too challenging to figure out. After figuring out what needs to be done, you may still need to take a few tries at it before succeeding, but it isn't usually too frustrating.

It is quite a short game if you figure out the puzzles quickly, it took me maybe 6 hours. So I probably wouldn't buy it for full price just because of the length, but I would definitely buy it on sale. Also, the soundtrack is a great jazz compilation.

One last note: at I believe the end of the first act, there are two endings depending on if you just stand and watch, or actively do something (I don't want to give spoilers) If you don't do anything, you'll fail the level and be put back to the beginning of the dialogue, so I recommend just listening first, then actually doing what you're supposed to.

Instead of investing into in-game videos, the developers invested into some pretty good voice acting, making the result inventive and convincing.\n\nThere are some technical bugs, but nothing preventing finishing the game or frustrating enough to stop playing it. I'm definitely looking forward to the next game (hopefully there will be one :) )

reviewText: Contrast is a game with problems, but that doesn't mean it isn't a great game. It is a game full of character and atmosphere with plenty of fun and extremely creative puzzle-solving missions. The ending is somewhat abrupt at 2 or 3 hours in, and leaves some questions unanswered and open to interpretation, but it is still satisfying while leaving room open for future instalments.\n\nIn short, it could have been polished a bit better, but there's a great gem here full of life and color (despite presenting a world of colorless shadows), and at $15 it's worth every penny.
